Bandar Seri Begawan, Brunei Darussalam

review_body: I have stayed at this hotel at least 3 times. For Americans, you will feel very comfortable in this hotel. You will also feel very large as the Japanese tend to require less space that we over fed American do; none the less the rooms are nice and are comparable to hotels in the U.S. You will find the bed a bit short but nothing that will cause you to loose sleep.In the hotel are several different restaurants that should satisfy the traveler. The top of the Dome hosts a bar seen that if I spoke Japanese and were 20 years younger would be a place I would want to go for night life. I would avoid weekends at this location as each time I was there, local families would arrive with children. I it was kind of like going to the Disney Land Hotel, lots of running up and down the halls and more noise than I wanted being away from home on a weekend.Breakfast! I emphasize this because breakfast in countries other than the United States can be a sobering experience. The Tokyo Dome has as I recall two or maybe three different breakfast menus/locations. You will get close to what is familiar to you in the American dinning room. If you pick the Japanese dinning room, you are more adventuresome than I.There are many places to walk to from the hotel for shopping, small local restaurants and a magnificent park right next door. I should not forget to mention that the name of the place indicates its right next door to the Tokyo Sport Arena. I watched a couple of Japanese Big League games there. You will be able to follow the game as Baseball is international but you will also find real cultural differences in the grandstands. Not bad, just different. My last note of caution, don't order what looks like a hot dog, its actually a fish dog. I watched my good friend almost choke to death after the first bite; I never laughed so hard; stick with the beer, its predictable.

I stay here 5-6 times per year and am consistently disappointed in room availability and the hotel's concept of customer loyalty.For instance, just checked in for a five day visit - - Made the reservation months ago, but no upper floor non-smoking rooms were available.- Requested to be put on a wait list for a higher floor (understanding the rate goes up), but that concept was just too much for them.- As I checked in just now, no upgrades available and no double rooms, non-smoking away from the elevator were initially available. I sort of had to stand firm and they finally found one for me.- Rates used to be competitive - especially for a hotel with old, stained carpets - but have significantly increased over the last year - even with early reservations.I'm checking into availability at the Edmont Metropolitan and getting out of here tomorrow. Service is great , the rooms are updated and rates can still be competitive.Pity.

The hotel is ideally situated near a metro station with easy access around the city. The rooms are clean, spacious and modern with very good wi-fi connection. The hotel has plenty of amenities and restaurants and the staff are very friendly, helpful and polite. We had slight issue with the air con on the first night and told the reception in the morning, by the time we returned at the end of the day from sightseeing the problem was fixed. I will definitely stay here again when I return to Tokyo.

We stayed for 2 nights. The room was surprisingly very spacious and there's free Wi-Fi. My only problem is that the pillows were too flat to give the right support. You can get access to Suidobashi Station (Mita Line) within 3-mins and Korakuen Station (Marunochi Line) with a slow walk of about 10 mins. The location is very near to La Qua entertainment zone with amusement rides, bowling, skating, eateries and shopping. A good place to stay if you want to away from the overcrowded city centre.

The hotel is very good. The room was large even if it was a 3 occupancy room. The service was excellent. We were not able to try the restaurants inside the hotel because the area of the hotel half so many restaurants. If you are traveling with children, beside the hotel is an amusement park that offers rides and illumination attraction at night. Regarding shopping, There is a mall with a supermarket a short distance from the hotel and there is a convenience store right outside the hotel. Access to travel is very easy because there is a metro station right where the hotel is (15-20 meter walk from the hotel entrance). Overall, even if the hotel is not in a major tourist area, the less crowded location and the easy accessibility of the hotel made it an ideal place to stay in.

Stayed for 6 nights. Right next door to the Tokyo Dome Baseball stadium. 2.5km walk to Imperial Palace. Train station on-site. Dozens of eateries and convenience stores (Lawsons and 7-11) within 100m.Good service. Many staff speak moderate English. Rooms are small-ish but comfortable with 'American style' toilet with bidet function if you choose. Plenty of hot water in shower-bath. Beds are certainly firm by USA, Australian and SE Asian standards. Fridge + mini-bar. Tea making (buy milk and sugar from convenience store). Very clean. Small desk. FREE wi-fi. CNN is only English language channel on TV. Adjustable AirCon.ASK for non-smoking room AND non-smoking floor - otherwise its a lottery.Automatic teller in lobby - DONT USE IT. Walk 50m to 7-11 and use the Bank 7 ATM - much better exchange rates. And buy some snacks etc.Personally, I would not pay for breakfast at the hotel (usually do). So many eateries and bakeries nearby which are cheap (coffee and ham and cheese muffin for $US7) and easy to use - every restaurant has pictographs on the counter for non-Japanese to easily order food and coffee etc without hassle. Food is generally cheap. Choose from Japanese, Korean, American style outlets (TGI Fridays at The Dome).Catch the 'special' bus from Narita Airport (buy tickets on rightside as you exit the customs area) - about $US30/$A35. Hour long trip but straight to the door. They load and unload you luggage. NO TIPPING!Taxis super clean and efficient. They automatically open the kerb-side rear door. DONT get in the other side. Fairly expensive. Take you destination/ hotel details in Japanese or on a map - drivers speak little English and have trouble with accents. NO TIPPING.Overall, a good place to stay just outside of the very centre of Tokyo. Flat walk everywhere or catch the trains.

This is a large 4-star luxury hotel. I had a 3- person room, which is very spacious, with three double beds, instead of the usual 2 double beds + 1 sofa bed. The wifi in room is free and efficient. The furnishings are not luxurious but still fine and agreeable. The best is the very convenient location. There is an amusement park and plenty of restaurants just next door. It is within five minutes walk from both the rail and subway stations. And from there, it is only about 10 minutes by train to Toyko central - the business, commercial and entertainment centre. Despite the above, the room charges are surprisingly inexpensive by Tokyo standard. This is probably because it is rather difficult to fill up so many rooms in the hotel, except on days where there is an event next door in the Dome. Ask for rooms in the higher floors facing the Dome. The scenery especially at night is beautiful. These rooms are of course more expensive.

Came here with a guided tour on a company trip with colleagues. This is one of the most popular hotel in Tokyo because of the stadium beside. It hosted one of the top baseball team in Tokyo and the baseball match can get really really crowded. The hotel is clean and great location. Feel safe staying in the hotel, when encounter strong winds and storm, the hotel is safe place to be at. Right opposite, there are big mall and amusement park.

One of the best in Tokyo. There service is awesome. They are perfect and damm good. I wish you a pleasant stay. There service is awesome and everything seems perfect. I liked there room window view most.

Very clean, fantastic location to train station with loads of amenities just below in the form of malls and an amusement park. Restaurants including a kaitenzushi is within reach, perfect for families keen to spend time with kids at a small-scale amusement park away from the crazy crowds at USJ or Disneyland. Hotel room was larger than most Japanese hotels, and had a large glass window with superb view of the city skyline, ferris wheel (the world's first center-less wheel) and roller coaster.

I was staying there for a week and all days are great! Nice room with play park view, so nice at night with lights in outside. Hotel bit busy back then because it was holiday season. Staff are excellent, my difficulty to communicate with them is because some of them are not speaking English. Near to train station, just 5-8 minutes walking. You also easy to find convenient store, coffee shop, and restaurant around the hotel.

Stayed for two nights for business as it was close to the client's office. Many of the guests were Japanese with a few Westerners. The hotel staff's English skills were not super proficient, but they were certainly pleasant and trying to help with restaurant recommendations.Quite near the train station, so easy to get around if using the train.Taxis were a bit hard to get in the morning.They do have a shuttle to the hotel at a reasonable fee, though it didn't run frequently enough for me to use it.

On our first trip to Tokyo this was the hotel we chose for the "city" part of our holiday. To start with, from Narita Airport there is a wonderful coach service called Airport Limousine which is really easy to find (after you exit arrivals head to the information desk) The coach drops you right outside the hotel which makes things a lot easier when you have just come off a 12 hour flight! The hotel itself is large and accommodates a lot of people. During our stay, the people visiting the hotel were predominantly Japanese (It always makes me feel like i have made a good choice when there are locals around!) The rooms were spacious and provided all amenities - be warned though, only green tea/ Oolong tea bags were provided which meant my morning coffee was not catered for! There are many (MANY) local convenience stores (7 Eleven, Lawsons ) around the hotels which meant i was able to pick up some instant coffee and milk for those 3am jet lag induced mornings. We didn't spend too much time in the hotel as Tokyo is a city to be explored! But we started our mornings at the breakfast buffet which were large and had pretty much everything a standard western buffet would have (there was also the option of a Japanese style breakfast...however this was served on another floor) We ended each evening in the cafe on the 3rd floor and treated ourselves to one of their lovely desserts and a cappuccino. As we visited in January the pool was not available for use - it would of been nice to have an indoor option or a sauna to relax in after a full day out of exploring this wonderful city! All in all our stay at the Tokyo Dome hotel was great - it is wonderfully located near the subway lines & many many restaurants giving a wide choice for the evenings. The staff are all very polite and helpful, and were very understanding of us not being able to speak any Japanese! Special recommendation to the ladies at the concierge who helped plan our days in Tokyo with such knowledge.

Staff are friendly and speak very well English. Its location is perfect connected to the metro line and a short walk to other lines. The view from the room to Tokyo Dome is fantastic and the rest of Tokyo is breathtaking! Plenty of eating places are located on the ground floor. A perfect stay.

Tokyo dome was located right next to the dome and it has a mall across the road. This gives a lot of benefit to the hotel stay. Transportation is amazingly convenient and also the hotel itself was very cozy and comfortable. Good restaurants and shopping malls are close so don't hesitate to stay here.

The hotel is very nice,clean. The rooms are clean, only complain the beds to low and hard mattress, my husband was the only one who didn't complain about it. Buffer breakfast big variety af Japanese and international food . Excellent costumer service .

I arrived at the hotel about 7am after an over night flight, my initial booking had an extra charge of JPY5000 for an early check in, but the staff insisted that I had to pay for a full day rate if I checked in then or wait for couple of hours to check in which the early check in fee of JPY5000 would cover. I just could not believe the attitude and inflexibility they demonstrated, compared with other hotels. I ended up paying a full day rate of JPY16,000 to check in at 7am as I could not sit at the lobby for 2 hours after a whole night flight.When I asked to have a bit late check out, an hour or two, I was told I had to check out at 11am as they are busy and can't provide any late check out at all.Would I recommend this hotel to anyone, the answer would be NO. I am their regular guest as our office is nearby, but this experience made me very very disappointed. It shows they don't think or care about their guests needs at all.

This hotel has a big and grand lobby well decorated for the coming Christmas festival. It is ideally situated near to shopping complex and a subway station. There is even an amusement park behind the hotel. This hotel is 43-storey high and is serviced by transparent capsule lifts to enable hotel guests to have a good view of the hotel surroundings. However, it is not situated at the Tokyo city centre.The hotel room is big, clean and spacious with an executive table. There is a swimming pool at the hotel. The hotel staffs are friendly, helpful and polite. It has a big restaurant that serves a variety of food besides Japanese cuisine. Here you also need to line up for breakfast as the number of hotel guests is big. One set-back is the toilet faucet controls are old fashioned. It is difficult to control the water temperature. Otherwise I have no complain about this hotel. Do not expect the type of hospitality as you can find in Sapporo!

Hotel is situated above Suidobashi metro station. Room is clear and spacious by Tokyo standard. Many things around the hotel: shopping, restaurant, fast food, convenient store, Starbucks, MacDonald, subway, small theme park. Rates are reasonable. I would recommend this.

I stayed at the Tokyo Dome for 5 nights and I couldn't have been more pleased. The staff provided the excellent Japanese service standard that I have come to expect from many years of traveling here and the rooms are much larger than most Japanese hotels. The room has wifi with good connection speeds and while there is only 1 English channel on TV (CNN) there is a speaker in the bathroom, so you can clearly hear the news while you get ready.While there are not any blockbuster sites nearby, the location is convenient for many business travelers and there is a Japanese garden nearby as well as many shops, stores and restaurants. There is a direct bus service from the airport for 3,100 Yen, which while expensive is certainly convenient. Note that the hotel can be busy during certain events and the price can fluctuate wildly based on occupancy.

I travel frequently for work and I stay in hotels for over 300 days per year (My membership status: SPG Platinum, Hilton Honors Gold, Marriott Rewards Gold, Hyatt Gold Passport Platinum, Langham Voyager). Never have I been so infuriated with the front desk staff that I feel compelled to write a review. On the morning of checkout, I called the front desk around 9ish to ask about the checkout time. I was told it was 11am. I then proceeded to ask for late checkout which was granted until 1pm. Imagine my astonishment when I proceed to checkout and my invoice reflected a 8100yen fee for late checkout. I explained that I had requested and had been granted the extension and asked that the fee be removed but the staff rejected my request. At this point, in what I can only assume to be the manager came out to clarify their stance. I reiterated my point to which the manager asked for the name of the staff who granted me the late checkout extension. I was flabbergasted by his suggestion. Which normal person would think to ask for the name of the staff while requesting for late checkout? Ultimately, the fee wasn't waived and I can only say this level of service is not befitting of a 4 star hotel.

I've stayed in this hotel on Feb. 2014 and Feb. 2015 for business. As a star level hotel, especially in Tokyo, the room is consider "really" huge. As expected Japanese style- very clean, great service, and well-trained staff. There's many elevators and they function well as you don't need to wait to long if your room is on the higher floors. The morning buffet offers many choices from Japanese style breakfast to western choices. 3-4 metro stations are within 5 mins walk. Indoor shopping center and hot spring facility are within 5-10 mins walk. Lots choices of restaurants/ stores nearby.

Having decided that was an appropriate title I then read a number of reviews from Japanese who were as scathing as I intended, so perhaps it is just BEWARE.So the location is busy, but not quite in the centre of things. Near 2 stations, but unless you read Japanese and know where you need to go this is not very useful. A taxi would be more appropriate. As others have said, check-in was slow and poor quality service. Extremely busy foyer. Poorly signed. Lots of staff who were not helpful. The room: large (excellency suite) and adequately appointed, but the bed!!!! Awful. Very hard. I thought probably for use by locals who might prefer hard beds, but the Japanese reviews belie that thought. They found them too hard as well. The solution (not quite satisfactory) is to double up the quilt and use that as a mattress topper, turn up the room temperature and sleep above the quilt. This was a very uncomfortable couple of nights and after a 12 hour flight it was not what I wanted (or expected). Staff seemed unperturbed by my observations. Other complaints? Expensive drinks. Even the in-room coffee had to be paid for! And the TV was Japanese only unless paid for. WiFi was free, which is good. No iron. Restaurants and bars seemed to be there for the benefit of the staff rather than the customers (early and very prompt last orders). Even in Excellency floors (40-43, so very high) the noise of the trains was disturbing. At that height why not double glaze it properly to reduce noise? Also, in an area with lots of hospitals and police stations, there were lots of sirens at night. I know, because I couldn't sleep on the hard bed!!All in all, AVOID this hotel if possible. Others I have stayed in are much better. Hope this helps you avoid a disaster.

Spacious rooms every one with a spectacular view of the city (we were on the 27th floor).Magnificent views are also to be had from the glass elevators - do try them all ... !!Once again no coffee sachets but there are two 7-11 stores within a 5 minute walk.Located next to the Tokyo Dome stadium, an amusement park (with ferris wheel, roller coaster etc) and shopping centre - it is a very busy precinct but no noise to be heard (ever from the rock concert held in the Dome one night).Two railway stations also within handy walking distance and a great public garden/park around the corner.Rooms were well presented and the bathroom the most spacious of all the hotels we had stayed in.This is the only hotel that had provided towelling dressing gowns but as I am larger than a Japanese person it did not fit. (I am sure I could have requested anther but did without).

Nice hotel for a night rest, near Tokyo dome and very nice place to walk around. Hotel is clean and come with wifi... View from my hotel room is superb...Staff in hotel are nice and professional.. Near train station, ease of Travelling but for first timer like me using the trains.. It can be quite complicated.. But it's easy to get the hang of it eventually

The Dome is celebrating it's 15th year now and to be honest is getting a little tired.But - it's not expensive and is in a great location for business and tourism. For such a large hotel the staff do pretty well and the rooms are clean and presentable - for me the beds are a little on the hard side but that's better than all soft and squidgy.It is busy - busier than most hotels so don't panic, just get on with it.I've been many times now and go to the local Starbucks (opens at 7) for my breakfast rather than fighting for survival in the hotel breakfast area.Would I go back - yes

Tokyo dome is not a quiet hotel. It's part of a major mix-use development project that features a major league baseball stadium and a full-fledged city amusement park. So all the pros and cons of such project apply in full force.On the plus side, all aspects of convenience are high at Tokyo Dome. There are plenty of places to eat around the hotel. Convenient stores, cafe, and nightspots are all within short walking distance. Suidobashi subway station, the closest one, is on the street corner. Korakuen station on another subway line is a bit farther to the north. JR Suidobashi station is just across the street.On the negative side, the hotel is always busy. At all hours, you see people come and go. A large coach dumping a big group of tourists on the hotel door step. Luckily, the baseball season was largely over when we were there, I can only imagine how busy and noisy it would be when the game is on.Rooms are very spacious, neat, and clean.The bathroom is the standard modular one-piece lift-and-install that seems to be the norm these days in Japan. Which is another way of saying that it's functional, but you're not going to have a luxuriating experience soaking in its bathtub. Deco, furniture, bedding, and amenities are all properly accounted for but tend toward practical and of average quality rather than pampering.Taken together Tokyo Dome is a good value. However, there is one caveat. Because of the nature of the property, if you value peace and quiet, you might want to check if there is a major event or baseball game going on during your stay.

This hotel is located in Tokyo Dome City with has a large number of different restaurants plus the amusement park. Hotel is comfortable and the staff is gracious and very helpful. Close to subways - will stay there again when we are in Tokyo.

Much more comfortable than a first impression would give you. In the Dome hotel you are close to a subway station which comes convenient. As the name says it is close the to the sports arena where the Tokyo baseball team is playing. The rooms are spacious, clean and all comfort is on board. THe hotels has a couple of restaurant but as the city has so much to offer I didn't really test them out. The place is huge so it can get croweded at the elevators and reception desk.

When I entered hotel lobby, so many people were there. I thought some sort of function was going on. The first impression was JUST busy busy ...The first thing i do in the room is always ... little bit of study about location hotel facility, All tour&area information packages in the room were also Japanese.Try to find concierge, elevator, subway station, even breakfast restaurant.This hotel has no signage in English or Japanese in side hotel. I was booked for 3nights, but since I had first terrible breakfast(not inc hotel accommodation) I had to decided to move out...when I checked out, so many staffs were doing nothing.for my checking out ceremony (?) total 3staff was attended. Didn't even know how to change 3nights to 1night statement. I was surprised they didn't ask me the reason why I made early check out.Staff with no knowledge... I hope They think what sort of industry there at in.

I couldn't say more about this hotel but it's one of the best ones I stayed in Tokyo given a nice price (booked thru Agoda). Staff are accommodating and ready 24 hrs. You can leave your bags after checkout if you plan to stay longer in Tokyo for shopping before leaving to another area. Noise level good as the area is sleeping by 12am. You can do your emergency shopping at the nearby variety store which is open 24 hours 7 days a week. And plenty of option for food around the area. There is also a mall and a theme park.All in all, a good stay!

Had a two night stay here and found it to be pretty much on par with most mid-range Holiday Inn or Marriott hotels. Room was Western sized, with a very large bathroom. I had a two double bed room, beds were basically single beds so don’t plan to put 4 people in the room. And as others have mentioned, they were Japanese traditional style designed for people used to sleeping on tatami mats. So if you like an extra firm mattress you would be very happy. Although no one in our group was complaining about the bed hardness.They were celebrating that the hotel was 15 years old, and guess what, the room décor is that old. It’s well kept, but it is dated looking. The breakfast buffet was pretty good, had a decent range of Asian and Western items. Right now it appears they are catering heavily to Chinese tour groups, so watch out in the morning as the large groups will all come down at exactly the same time (like 7:30 AM).The hotels is part of the Tokyo Dome baseball stadium/amusement park/shopping mall complex so lots of shops, and there is a Don Quixote about 2 blocks up from the east exit of Suidobashi station by the hotel.For some reason the hotel web site makes you think it’s a hike to get to the hotel. Best method is to take the East exit form Suidobashi station, turn to the left and walk to the intersection and spot the Starbucks across the street. Then look a little bit to the left & look up. The hotel is right there. If you go out the West exit, do the same thing but do everything to your right.About the only big drawback to this hotel is it’s not in a convenient spot for getting around Tokyo for sightseeing by using the trains, and especially from the airport. Even though it’s kind of in the middle of the center of the Yamanote line loop, it’s not close to any of the key areas. And the Chuo line is limited unless you want to go to Shinjuku or Akihabara where you will make transfers. So plan on making a lot of transfers if you are using either JR or Tokyo Metro, or using cabs. Download Hyperdia to your phone, you will need it to make your train routes.

This hotel Iocated right next the stadium, Tokyo Dome theme park and opposite the train station. We were on the 31 floor and the views where just beautiful. The rooms were a good size with a queens size bed.

my European flight landed on schedule in Narita Tokyo at 07.45 in the morning. Consequently, I reached Tokyo Dome hotel at a quarter to 10.00am (with train to Ueno station and then a taxi = altogether less than 3000 yen). Regardless of travelling in the business class, I felt like a whiplashed dog when I dragged my feet in the hotel lobby and asked for their mercy to clean a checked out room and put an end to my misery of sleeplessness. They claimed that the hotel was fully booked the previous night (it was Saturady night to Sunday) and so no early availability was open. Thus I had to wait until 15.00, that is around 5 hours! I managed to wald around for 1 hour, then to have something to eat at their lobbly area and at 12.45 I asked again for their mercy. This time, they kept me for 20 more minutes, gave me a room and charged me 1000 yen additionally. This would never happen in any European hotel, as at least they would be calling me in one hour maximum after my early arrival and they would charge me for any surplus, but I would not wait for more than 3 hours, after 2 consecutive flights of 3 and 11 hours from Europe. Now if we forget all this upsetting ouverture, the room was very clean but small, the bed was OK, the 6th floor bar was charging a lot for one third of the typical European dose of Macallan whisky and the breakfast was Ok.. Prepare yourself if you are booked with this hotel.

We got an upgrade from a two star pension to this hotel due to over booking,so we were already quite pleased with the situation. Nevertheless the hotel is beautiful,the rooms are big and the panorama from our window was breathtaking. The service is perfect and the position ideal for visiting Tokyo,just a stroll from JR and subway stations.Recommended

I would call this a modern Japanese hotel - Western amenities with some Japanese quirks.Our two bed room had space for a desk, lounge chair, and window seat. And also had enough room to spread one suitcase out in the closet and one tossed open behind the desk. The beds are those lower than American standard, extra firm (hard) one that you find in most Japanese business hotels; though sheets and comforters provided enough softness to make it bearable. You get used to it. The maid staff was very attentive and kept everything clean. But the hotel has a difficult to understand "ECO" policy/indicator so sometimes the towels and cups did not get changed when we wanted them to be.The Western style breakfast buffet is larger than most I've been too so there are options for every. I lot of Japanese food in the buffet so you really need to only go to the Japanese breakfast room just once (coffee is free at the buffet but 600 yen at the Japanese breakfast room). The Whiskey Bar on the top of the hotel has a great view.One disappointment is the lack of a fitness room or pool. Looked like there was a good fitness gym nearby but it won't give you a day pass. I would encourage the hotel to work out a partnership with nearby gyms.The hotel is located in a entertainment complex so there is always something going on: shows, exhibitions, so great people watching. And great amenities like food courts, toy stores, souvenir shops, sporting goods stores, bowling alley, amusement park. The shopping mall across the plaza and stores across the street has all you need for shopping too: Uniqlo, Muji, grocery store, Don Quixote, etc..I would recommend this hotel for business travelers because it is right next to the Suidobashi Station on the Chuo Line. That train connects Shinjuku to Tokyo Station. Easy to go to subway station too. Especially convenient for those with work at the Universities or National government (there are no modern hotels in those areas). I would also recommend this hotel for families that want a hotel very close to train and subway in the central part of the city. So much for kids to do around this hotel and there is the modern conveniences of Starbucks, McDonalds, etc...

Tokyo Dome Hotel is situated at a convenient location with plenty of amenities around the hotel. The rooms are quiet (very important) and spacious (western style). Service is as usual superb when in Japan. A lot of tourists stayed in this hotel so it's busy all the time especially during breakfast time. Breakfast spread was pretty good but just too many people making it difficult to enjoy my breakfast.

The Tokyo Dome hotel is located next to a sports arena and amusement park. The rooms are rather small and need some upgrade. The executive lounge on 40 floor is very nice and good service. The restaurants in the hotel are rather expensive

The location is so convenient as it is just outside 2 different subway station that connect you to e.g. Akihabara.We stayed on level 28, which had an amazing view over the Dome city and the roller coaster. The room itself was spacious and the bathroom was clean.Make sure to head up to the roof top bar as this gives you another great view over the city

Considering the size of the hotel as well as the rooms, this is one of the better hotels in Tokyo. The hotel is situated really close to Suidobashi station, which is just a 5 to 10 minutes walk away by foot. The station doesn't have any direct lines to Tokyo station, so it's not extremely convenient to get onto the Yamanote line, but it does provide direct shuttle bus services to both airports.The check in and out were done very quickly and efficiently by the hotel staff. The staff are also able to speak English to a certain extent, which may serve as a sigh of relief for some visitors. The rooms are clean and big by Japanese standards. Get a higher floor for a magnificent night view of Tokyo dome and the close by shopping mall - Laqua. Amenities provided by the hotel are the usual, nothing spectacular to rave about. The beds might be a little stiff and the pillows are a little on the shallow side. The Wi-Fi signal is really strong and is more than enough to cover even video streaming.The toilets are huge compared to the usual Japanese standards, and they come with a bath tub and sink, which is quite rare if you were to stay in other business hotels. There are two restaurants that serve breakfasts at this hotel. One is the international buffet spread on the 3rd floor, and the other, a traditional Japanese breakfast on the 4th. The international spread is decent and caters to a larger, more eclectic crowd. However, the dishes don't change at all, so be prepared to be seeing the same dishes throughout your entire stay. The traditional Japanese breakfast is essentially a set meal, but it was surprisingly good. I'm not sure if the menu is changed regularly though. There are several shops in the vicinity that one might be keen to explore. The most obvious one being the large shopping mall - Laqua, which is just a 15mins walk away. There's also don Quixote (something like a large convenience store), 7-11, Starbucks and Macdonald's all close-by. Really fantastic place to stay, despite the minor inconvenience of having to change trains to get to the city or more touristy places. Nevertheless, a 'highly recommend' from me.

The Tokyo Dome Hotel is beautiful hotel. Very nice and rooms are spacious and their breakfast is very good. A lot of selections and it was very good. We enjoyed our stay there. Next to a amusement area with roller coast rides and a lot of shopping. Great place to stay near downtown Tokyo.

Not sure how this hotel gets a 4star rating. It's fine for business and location isn't too bad, clise to train stations. Hotel room was clean but looks like it hasn't had a facelift in 20years. Tv only had Japanese speaking channels, no cable. Bathroom again clean but outdated, horrible shower curtain to pull across the side of the bath, old add on shower attachment for having a shower in the bath. Nice view.

The only good thing about this hotel is the location and wifi. Very convenient in going to and from the metro, subway or JR line.The room may be spacious but a lot of things are missing; no complimentary water, coffee, etc. Bathroom looks very ordinary with cheap toiletries. Beds are very low and hard, mattress and pillows are not of good quality.Housekeeping didn't replace our towels and when we arrived at night, our towels were still wet since those were used in the morning before we went out.TV channels are all in Japanese. There are no non-smoking rooms. Hallways smells like smoke and carpets in the hallways looked old and dirty.

The hotel itself is nice, near restaurant and shopping center.I had been there with my family .The hotel rooms were very clean and comfortable with a good service.the food here was nice too but a bit expensive...I felt headache for about check in....have to wait for a long time!!!!

The rooms are perfect, slightly bigger than the traditional Japanese hotels . This has the dome which is very close & if you are interested in events like baseball or a music concert its ideal . There is also a kids amusement place next door. Its a very comfortable place and the staff is very friendly . Its worth going to the restaurant on the roof top for some amazing views.

I travel a lot, both on business and pleasure, and I've stayed in many budget hotels and dormitories, but the mattress in this hotel was well, probably the worst.I would describe the stiffness of the mattress as equivalent of a economy class seat in an airplane. Even train seats and car seats are softer than this.It's pretty much the same as sleeping on a carpeted floor.Which is such a shame, because other than that, the room was spacey and comfortable, and everything else was fine. (Well, except, the towel hanger in the bathroom is very low and literally right next to the toilet, which made the towel hung there seem a little filthy...)But the location is good if not great, considering that a lot of reasonable priced hotels in Tokyo are a little bit far from train stations where as this hotel is right above the subway station, and there are plenty of places to eat around the area, so you won't have to exhaust yourself walking to the hotel dragging your suitcase or simply after a long hard day, get a quick bite, and go to bed.So if you're content to have a flat surface to sleep on, this is a fair choice, but if you want your bed to comfortably support your exhausted body, by all means, KEEP AWAY!!

This is truly a great & grand hotel as the service provided by the reception are utmost highest standard. Nearby many spot for you to have your dinner without spending too much. The Room is comfortable especially the night view from the room is perfect and worth staying for couple of nights.

Very nice hotel, with big rooms. I really loved the location. Next to tokyo dome, theme park, shopping center and alot of resturants and coffee shops. Very to the train station, just 3 minutes. The check in is really a headache. There is no early check in, not even 5 minutes. Means all guests have to queue for long time. Also the furniture needs little update.I recommend it.

Our final one night stay before ending the Hokaiddo tour. The views from the window in our hotel room is very very beautiful to look at during night time with Tokyo Dome and the Ferris Wheels ahead. The breakfast buffet is really assorted and high quality. I have no idea how much this hotel cost per night but am GLAD that we get to stay at this nice and grand hotel. Definitely, if travel to Tokyo without joining package tour again, will consider this hotel.

The location is perfect with lots of places to see in the surrounding area. Close to the station and the room just good size. The only problem is that the bed is quite low and a bit hard. The lobby is huge but lots of people on standby.

I've stayed at the Tokyo Dome Hotel for business 3 times in the last 2 years as our headquarters is within walking distance to the hotel. As you can see from pictures, it's a high-rise hotel with minimalistic rooms, yet comfortable and quiet. I was a bit surprised by the somewhat basic rooms as I guess I expected a few more amenities. That said, I was not in the room very much and for the amount of time I spent in it, it got the job done. I was always able to connect to wi-fi, the bed mattress was hard, yet comfortable for me (as I like a harder mattress versus a soft mattress), the room and hallway were quiet and water pressure for the shower was very good. The room itself was quite clean upon arrival and every day after it was serviced.If you are going to an event at the Tokyo Dome, this hotel is a great option as it's right there next to the venue. The location also allows for good restaurant options within easy walking distance of all types of cuisine (American, Italian, Japanese, chain type restaurants (TGI Fridays), etc. The only drawback for me is the TV doesn't have english channels. Unless your Japanese is very good, watching TV is not a good option. After a long day at work, it would be nice to come back and have some sort of foreign (CNN, SKY, Sports) channel available. Not the case here.For the price however, this hotel gives you the basics for a good nights sleep and the ability to get good connectivity in your room. Two key aspects of any hotel room. I'd go back, especially for the price in an overall expensive city.

I was priveleged to stay here as a guest for a wedding party in 2014. I love Tokyo and this hotel was in a handy location and ticked all the boxes for me. The night views were amazing and going down the glass walled lift was a great experience too. The room was kept at a comfortable temperature and had all the expected amenities. It was clean, comfortable and had enough space for me to be able to relax and rewind in. The hotel has a variety of shops and restaurants, friendly, helpful staff and a great location for getting about the city. Highly recommended!

Hotel was a great location as we were visiting a conference at the conference centre but also easy access to the underground train network.The hotel staff were very friendly and helpful.The room was very comfortable and clean.We only used the hotel cafe which was lovely but a little pricey although the amenities on the door step of the hotel meant we found good facilities at a reasonable price within walking distance.Definitely recommend and return.

Staff were all polite and friendly.I forgot my travel plug and they loaned me one without any fuss. Good wifi coverage. Not much choice for eating outside of normal dining hours but otherwise a problem free stay. Easy to get a taxi from the hotel.

Hotel is strategically located with several restaurants available within walking distance. Unfortunately no major malls nearby. Breakfast is great with plenty of choices. Long line for breakfast takes amazingly less than 10 minutes to be served

I was at the Dome for one night on business. I checked-in to room 4109 on July 16.The Dome is convenient because it's a five minute walk to our office. If you're a baseball fan, the hotel is right next door to the Tokyo Dome, home of the Yomiuri Giants. The hotel gets seriously busy on game nights or if there's a concert going on.The dome has 42 floors and a lot of rooms. Prices are reasonable. Location is not ideal as there aren't many sights in the area but it is a short walk to the subway and JR train stations. Convenient.Though old, it still carries a nice modern vibe. Brightly lit and spacious lobby. The door staff and bell team are super efficient in greeting you, taking your bags - storing them if your room is not ready - and seeing you to the check-in counter. They are outstanding.The check-in was longer than i think necessary. And, even if i have been to the hotel many, many times, they never acknowledge me or have my personal details printed in advance. I have to fill in my personal particulars every single time. They must have a seriously outdated CRM system.I settled for a smoking room as it was a last minute reservation and they were running full. It was a good excuse to try their Execellency Rooms (the equivalent of the Executive Floor, I guess). The bad news was they only had a smoking room left.Actually, the room size, bed and bath are similar to some of the non-Excellency rooms except for a fancier credenza and mini bar. The work desk and lounge chair is the same. The TV is also better but the selection of channels is the same...only CNN for English. The pillows are not the usual fluffy ones...flat and hard.The bath in this room is really good sized and very well lit. Complete amenities including a hair dryer. Good water pressure too.If you stay at the Excellency floor, you get access to the Excellency Lounge which is a charming and intimate space. You get a free continental breakfast. Nice. And you can check-out there, too.The Dome hotel is a reasonably good value. As such, it is very popular with tour groups so your patience may be stretched a bit if you happen to arrive at the same time. There could be as much as a 10 minute queue for the elevators. Oh well, a little group therapy every now and then won't kill you.

Their system and their staff for check in and check out are all good. Their staff can speak English. Free wifi in the room. Nice and clean room. Near from hotel, there are train station, convenient store, and mall.

Were it not for the concert we had to watch at the Tokyo Dome, I wouldn't have considered staying here. It is far from the city centre if your main reason is to explore Tokyo. Having said that, the rooms are big by Japanese standards and are very clean.

We went to japan during summer breaks. We had booked two rooms in Hotel Tokyo dome. Japan is an amazing summer destination especially when winters freezes you in New Zealand. Tokyo dome hotel was just the right place to stay in japan. We chose this hotel cause of the Tokyo dome and the skating and bowling center which lay nearby. The rooms were spacious with a wonderful Tokyo view and yet affordable for a family visit. Their services and hospitality was just adorable.The hotel made our stay more enjoyable and wonderful.We enjoyed and my son enjoyed the skating center more ;)

I've stayed in this hotel numerous times. It is located just in front of JR Suidobashi (next to Akihabara) and subway Suidobashi stations. Also, there are many restaurants and convenience stores around, so it's very convenient. The rooms are spacious and comfortable, although they are dated. The beds are relatively wide and fine, unless you only like very soft beds. Nice view from the bar at the top of the hotel. The Tokyo Dome City, where the hotel exists, has an Amusement Park, famous LaQua Spa, and over 50 restaurants, cafes and bars of wide ranges, which can satisfy everyones taste. http://www.tokyo-dome.co.jp/e/

Stayed here with my family from end April to May this year. It was part of a package deal from our local travel agency, so we got a discount. It met our requirements of being near a subway station (near two in fact!), surrounded by malls and very clean with good service. Now, for details:Location:It's walking distance from Suidobashi (JR and Toei) and Korakuen so easily accessible by public transport. Malls and convenience stores within walking distance. However, this hotel can get VERY VERY crowded when there's a show at the Tokyo Dome arena. This happened throughout our stay there with Paul McCartney concerts and Baseball games. The good thing about this is, the crowds are very organized. But a crowd is a crowd and waiting for the lifts became tiring sometimes, especially when we were rushing somewhere.Breakfast:We had a buffet breakfast at Rilassa everyday, as part of our package. We're vegetarians so the food was mostly the same on all 7 days. Limited breads, egg (fried/scrambled/plain omelette), hash brown/baked potatoes, fruits, cereals.. Not much hot food. In fact we were happy to see a tomato-based pasta but it turned out to have pork in the stock. But I think there was a very large variety of food for non-vegetarians.. the menu changed every day too.Service:Impeccable! We felt this way throughout our stay in Japan - people are extremely courteous and helpful!Amenities:We didn't really explore these. But the amusement park next door could provide loads of entertainment for bored kids!Cleanliness:Very clean. No complaints here. Towels were changed everyday. The hot water was working.. all good!Wifi:There was free wi-fi in the rooms and lobby. The signal was strong most of the time. Reliable.We enjoyed our stay!

Tokyo Dome hotel is one of the best i stayed in Tokyo. The staff are really good. They help you out arrange whatever traveling details you need. The rooms are nice. The view from the room is too good. Location is easy access to all the major trains. Also some small shopping arcade near by. Overall the hotel is good to stay if you are staying in Tokyo.

I was on a group tour and stayed at this hotel for a night. This is next to the Tokyo Dome which can be crowded if there are events for the night. It's a short walk to the subway, there's a amusement area and shopping complex with restaurants in the area and Don Quixote is only a 5 minute walk! Hence even if the shopping complex is closed, you can still continue shopping at Don Quixote which opens till late.Rooms are very comfortable and I really enjoyed the view of the amusement park at night. Wifi in rooms were of reasonable speed. Breakfast spread was good but the service was slow and they seem a little understaffed.

I have never written a review I'm not one to brag or complain but this has by far been the worse experience I have ever had . I'll try to make this short . It's my first time here in Tokyo . I got in and notice they lost my luggage its been quite a battle trying to retrieve my things . Got to the hotel where I booked through agoda I booked one room for my husband and I only for them to say I booked 1 room for one person if It was to be the two of us I needed two beds for two ppl " we'll have to charge you double " they said . which I argue " if that was the case cancel my reservation I'll go somewhere else " after about 5 min the person at the counter says " no ! no !we're sorry there was a misunderstanding somewhere along those lines our mistake we'll take care of it with no extra charge ". I asked " are you sure !?" which he repleid " yes ! " So now I'm in my room on the phone battling the airlines to try to locate my luggage . Three days later w/o any clothes my luggage comes in . The front desk phones us and says "mam your luggage has arrive please come down and sign for it and while you're here you still have to pay the difference of the balance for a two person stay . " Didn't you just said two / three days ago there would be no extra charge !? I was booked here for a 6 night stay . I cancel the rest of my reservation & still had to pay the difference for the two ppl room . Stupidest thing I have ever heard . When I booked this hotel I thought it would be in downtown Tokyo far from it . The only good thing about this place is the distance to and from the train station . Good luck !

The hotel is conveniently located near the metro station, coffee shops, restaurants, and convenient stores. I could imagine it getting quite noisy if there is a show on because it's right beside Tokyo Dome. The area more local than touristy. The rooms are spacious and clean. New furnishings.

Big great hotel in the center of everything.My room was clean and big with a fantastic view of this amazing city.There were no gym in the hotel ...Great bar at the top of the hotelThe sushi bar in the hotel is very expensive, good but expensive, go out ! you will find a lot of them. Don't worry if you're not speacking Japanese, you will always have the pictures to show to the waiter !I was able to walk to very interesting part of the city if you ready to walk so.

Stayed 2 nights in this hotel, it was my first in the hotel. The room was spacious & nice, the beds were comfortable, had a good sleep.. the beds were not hard at all in my opinion..i guessed this is something very subjective depending on each individual's liking..the breakfast was good with quite a a good spread..the location was convenient, near to the train station, plenty of restaurants nearby..there's a bar not too far away..nice place to wind down. the hotel is also not too far from tsukiji market, about 20 minutes by taxi.. the hotel staffs were nice and courteous..i had a good impression of the hotel and would be back

For first timers to Tokyo and with many luggage, the hotel is best accessed by airport limousine bus from both Narita and Haneda airports. But make sure to check the bus schedules carefully since they run at specific hours. Otherwise you’ll have to take the trains which is a bit more complicated because you need to change the station or either take a cab for the rest of the journey to reach the hotel. Please consult the Access Page of the hotel’s website which gives clear directions on the matter. Also check out the Airport Limousine Bus facebook for promotional fare packages. There are three main stations around the hotel. From the front entrance, turn left and in less than 5 min walk, passing by 7-11 and Starbucks on the left side, you’ll reach Toei Subway Mita Line’s Suidobashi Sta (A2 Exit) where there’s an elevator for those in need. If you cross the street at the intersection on the right side, you’ll reach JR Chuo Line’s Suidobashi Sta. However if you exit at the back of the hotel and walk through the amusement park and cross the street to the LaQua Complex side, turn left and walk a bit further you’ll reach Metro Marunouchi and Nanboku Lines’ Korakuen Sta. In my experience of using subway stations I’m happy to say that all the personnel took great care for people in wheelchairs. There might be elevators from the ground floor down to the platforms. But at old stations there’s quite a gap between the platform and the train itself, and that’s why we were accompanied by at least 1-2 station staff carrying a portable ramp with them. They led us through to the designated place and notified the destination station of our group. When the train arrived and door opened, the staff would place the ramp down before wheeling me into that car and took a bow; we of course bowed back. We were met with the same procedure at the destination station. If it’s a new station, then only one staff would be there to see to our safety and guided us to the right exit. Japanese hospitality is truly awesome!Tokyo Dome Hotel opened since June 2000 with 43 floors and more than 1000 guest rooms. So you can imagine how crowded it would be at breakfast time. If your room rate doesn’t come with bf, then I’d suggest you book only a room. There are plenty of eateries nearby, plus 7-11 and Starbucks are right next door and across the street is McDonald’s. For other main meals, many restaurants of Japanese and international cuisine are within walking distance, either at the close by Meets Port or further back of the hotel at Amusement Park and LaQua Complex. If walking isn’t an issue then you may get off the front door on the 2nd floor, walk towards the yellow building and cross the pedestrian overpass to the West Exit of JR Chuo Line’s Suidobashi Station. There you’ll find many local eateries that offer tasty ramen at much lower prices. The hotel has many room sizes to suit your needs. My husband and I stayed in a Double room with an area of 26 m² while our children stayed in a Triple room of 33 m². I’d say it’s comfortable enough, neither big nor too small. Our bathroom however is rather compact. All amenities came at one set for each guest; a bit surprised to find soap instead of bath gel. But what I loved most is the Japanese toilet, very hygienic indeed! The Triple room’s bath is a wee bit bigger and better functional; the wash basin area is separated from the toilet/tub compartment that has a lockable door. Storage space for both room types is quite limited. Being an Asian myself and I like to sleep on firm mattress but the mattress in my room is really rather hard. Maybe it’s just this room, I don’t know. Due to tiredness I slept through anyway. My children said their mattresses are not this hard. Perhaps you could request for extra lining when reserving your room.Tokyo Dome Hotel is quite adjacent to the Big Egg or Tokyo Dome Stadium, which holds many big events all year round. The hotel is thus a popular venue for guests attending those events. This causes heavy traffic not only at breakfast buffet, where you need to get in line to be seated, but at elevators as well. The hotel has 8 elevators, with 4 elevators on the left serve up to 25th floor and another 4 on the right serve up to 41st flr. At times, at check in hours (14.00-16.00) there are two long lines for both the left side and the right side elevators. At least one bellboy (bellhop) stands by to direct guests to their elevators during traffic hours. Twice I had witnessed a disorderly scene with new tourist groups who had language barriers and were unfamiliar with queuing system. On the way down from your room, the wait time is about 5-10 min. So consider enough time allowance for the elevator when planning your schedule/itinerary.Need to know:- no free bottled water; you can buy from the near-by 7-11 shop- free tea sachets but coffee is NOT- guests staying on 9th-25th flr and wish to visit friends/relatives on higher floors must make a transfer on the 25th flr and continue with the elevators on the right side- mini fridge: On the eve night of our departure my son got so thirsty and he took a bottle of mineral water from the fridge. Very early next morning he bought the exact same bottle from 7-11 and replaced it in the fridge long before housekeeping cleaned the room. Yet at check out, he was charged for that bottle. I suspect this is a motion sensor fridge so don’t even touch or move anything or else you might be charged at check out.- direct booking at hotel website at least 2-3 months in advance for long stay exceeding two nights might get you a special rate, much cheaper than the rack rate and you can opt to pay directly at the hotel.

I've stayed in this hotel numerous times over the last five years. Staff: fantastically polite and courteous, honest to boot too.Location: Great for getting around with Metro(Ginza Line), JR stations all within a 5 minute walk. Airport limousine bus(orange one) provides door to door service to/from Narita Airport.Food: Average but tasty and varied breakfast buffet. Teppanyaki was fantastic!Rooms: They look dated and some rooms are tired and in need of a facelift but they are not run down. For the most part, the rooms are clean, well appointed and comfortable. Size wise, they are pretty good especially by Japanese hotel standards.Best commendation: Left a camera behind. Didn't realize until a few days later. Emailed them. They said, yes, we have your camera! Got a friend to pick it up.Interesting things nearby:There is a small supermarket located within the Tokyo Dome City complex(basement, near the musical fountain) which sells some pretty expensive wines: Ch.Ausone, Ch. Margaux, Sassicaia, etc.I'd give them 5 stars once they start updating the rooms.

Excellent Hotel with good connectivity to Public Transport (Limousine, Metro, Subway). Breakfast is with a wide menu with something for everybody to pick. Staff is courteous and most of all honest. A colleague of mine forgot 50,000.00 yens on his table and when we came back in the evening they were in the same place not even moved an inch (The housekeeping was done in our absence). There's a public garden nearby if you have time its worth a stroll. Be careful as the restaurant closes at 10:00pm sharp and then only room service is available with very limited options. There are a few Indian restaurants to nearby but be careful to avoid some spooky areas nearby. All in all a good value for money even if costly, but then quality comes for a price....

Rooms are very clean with a modern bathroom. The size is normal for Japanese standards. The beds are very old like others have articulated in reviews below.Hotel location by its namesake is ideal if you are attending a Giants game or local concert. Many good restaurant locations with several western choices including Bubba Gumps, Denny's, TGI Fridays but I do prefer the local cuisine - When in Rome... The breakfast is expensive but there are many choices leaning more toward Japanese tastes.The view from the top floor is worth the elevator ride. Expensive to eat or drink up there but worth it. There is a nominal fee to sit at a table which we were rudely reminded about by the staff.Great location but you need to get hammered to sleep in those ridiculously hard beds!

I've stayed at the Dome Hotel many times and decided to finally provide some feedback.The Good: excellent view of Tokyo, recommend floors above the 35th on the amusement park side. Very sound proof rooms as I've never been awaken from internal or external noise. The reception staff and concierges are is very friendly and can converse in basic English. Highly recommend a trip to the 43rd floor at dusk as the sun sets as the view is exceptional. The restaurant is pricy on the top floor but do stop for the view and a cold beverage as the view will not disappoint. The rooms are small but extremely clean. Love the house keeping staff in all of Japan as they do take pride in their work.The Bad: the beds are so hard and very old. I've been visiting this hotel for ten years and am sure the beds have not changed in a decade. You can feel springs coming out by placing your hand gently on the bed. I'm used to hard beds in Japan but when springs are sticking into your ribs it makes for a restless sleep.I'd give the hotel an extra star if the beds were replaced and the breakfast did not cost $25.00.

I've stayed in this hotel for two separate business trips about 5 years apart - and it remains a great value for a nice Western-style hotel in Tokyo. It's location right next to the Tokyo Dome ballpark seems a bit odd, but there are train stations right nearby (one practically under the hotel) and the Dome has its own entertainment and restaurant complex (and even an amusement park! Don't worry, the rooms are nicely soundproofed). Compared to other Tokyo hotels at similar prices the rooms are huge, and everything is wonderfully clean and staff is friendly. The breakfast buffet is enormous (but comes with an enormous price tag, as is always the case)!

The hotel seems huge with its nearly 50 storiesIt's has a huge lobby, but rooms are not that bigBreakfast is moderateThe location is very good , close to the dome and amusement park. As well as some good restaurants and convenience stores There is a train station near by as wellThe airport bus stops at the hotelYet more options for Haneda airport rather than NaritaThere is a safe box in the room

Excellent hotel and well positioned for exploring Tokyo or visiting concerts at the Dome centre.The rooms are well appointed and very comfortable. Hotel service is excellent and very efficient in true Japanese style. There are a number of bars and restaurants. We ate in the typical Japanese restaurant where we grilled our own exquiste tasty food at the table.I would not hesitate in recommending this hotel
