review_body: Staying at the tokyo dome hotel for 6 nights on our way home from Niseko to do all the tourist things. Was a bit unsure after we booked not knowing where in tokyo we were located or how close to things. We could walk out of the reception door and straight underground to a train station that got us to all the popular places within 15 minutes!Staff were great! Lots of options for dinner around, The dome is like its own little town, we didn't have to go more then 10 min for dinner each night :) Great view overlooking the amusement park. Rooms very spacious and large bed and bathroom!Would definitely stay again if we go back to Tokyo :)

Though the hotel is not located near central Tokyo, it is near 2 metro stations which makes it a convenient location for me. I like the room size of the twin bed room and tea bag is provided though one must pay for coffee. There is a amusement park nearby but one must try the LaQue spa which is a luxury Japanese hot bath. Do note that this hotel like most Japanese hotel I know, is very particular about check in and out time. We had to pay extra 1,000 yen to check in an hour earlier. Wifi strength is good in room and basic amenities like toothbrush, hairbrush, shampoo, conditioner, body bath, slippers, hairdryer and bathrobe are provided.

This was our first trip to Japan and the stay at Tokyo Dome Hotel was a great way to start the trip. It is well located very near the Suidobashi station on one side and Korakoen station on the other. We were a walking distance from L'Aqua, a shopping mall and Richmond, which is a 24-hour convenience store. This hotel is the pick-up point for many land tours so it was very convenient for us. We were traveling with a seventeen-month old baby so this arrangement was great!Breakfast is continental with Japanese dishes available. As we are vegetarians, we could have salad, fresh fruit together with the usual Western breakfast of cereal and various bread types. If anything, perhaps some cheese would have been nice but that's just a personal request.The staff are very friendly and efficient but this seems a way of life among the Japanese people. Every single one I met has been extremely polite and friendly and truly hospitable. Their demeanor only brings out the best in you. The rooms were comfortable. We were on the 35th floor and had adjacent rooms. Great housekeeping service and toilets were a joy to use. I always feel a good judge of a place is its toilets and Tokyo Dome takes the prize!I will certainly return to this hotel because it is one of the reasons I enjoyed my trip to Japan.As a point to be taken for consideration, the checkout time is 11am at the hotel. I've travelled reasonably widely and this is the first time I've had a checkout time as 11am. Checkin is 2 pm, which is the norm but checkout seems early. Perhaps the hotel could reconsider that.One more thing is that the hotel is right next to Tokyo Dome so it can be crowded with guests who are attending the events at the Dome. But the staff are well-equipped to handle big crowds so not a problem except that it can be crowded.

We stayed a night at Tokyo Dome Hotel and it was awesome. The room is spacious and we had a spectacular view of Tokyo Dome and the roller coaster which is only within 3 minutes walking distance. Further down about 5 minutes walking distance you will reach the shopping mall with garden and musical fountain. The hotel has plenty of exit towards Tokyo Dome: one from the lobby and the other from 3rd floor (where buffett breakfast is served).The room is clean with all toiletries available 8ncluding hair dryer. Fridge is well stocked but charges apply. Each room is supply with yukata (Japanese robe) too. Nearby there are plenty of restaurants and also convenience store.

Our family decided to stay here last April 9, prior to going home to the Philippines. Amazing view from our hotel room! It is centrally located and shopping malls near the hotel is the best in terms of cheap bags, etc. this hotel is very near the JR station and Tokyo Imperial Palace!

Very spacious standard rooms well equipped. Centrally located in Tokyo near a shopping centre with plenty of restaurants Japanese and Western and even a buffet style restaurant with enough variety to satisfy any western traveller. For baseball fans the hotel is next door to the Tokyo Dome Baseball arena. Breakfast is international and make the most of the fresh fruit and if you are lucky bananas will be available. Omlettes are cooked to order. If you are in a queue don't worry there is not a long wait before you are escorted to your breakfast table. Wi Fi is free. As in Japan porterage is not available.

We reached this hotel in the evening. Impressive looking hotel!It’s our last 2 days in Japan.Check-in was smooth. Our guide also provided us train maps and a hotel map for our connivance.Big lobby!Service staff - Great Room – 11th floor (Room view – hotel front and main road)Breakfast – Very Good (Western & Japanese’s)Sleep – GoodNearby – Can watch baseballs games @ Tokyo DomeCan shop around (shopping mall & supermarket), eateries, train stations, park & a mini “Theme-Park” with roller coaster and many other fun rides.We are satisfied with our stay at this hotel!Cheers!See Pics!

I have stayed all over tokyo and Tokyo Dome seems to be my favorite hotel and location to stay at. The rooms are more spacious than the usual tokyo standards. The location is convenient to the train and subway stations. There are plenty of restaurants and touristy activities directly outside the hotel. Lastly, it has a very convenient shuttle bus that takes you directly to the airport!

Nice, clean hotel. Room not overly big but then again this is Japan. Staff were helpful. The location next to an amusement park area which was surprising but good to visit at night. Food places around about not outstanding though.

Right by the Tokyo Dome baseball and leisure park, in the midst of more shops and restaurants that you can possibly want and pretty good for transport to the other parts of Tokyo. If there is a game on or activity at the Dome then it gets really really busy - the breakfast area becomes a bit on the hectic side really. I travel on business and whilst the breakfast selection is excellent it is more 'family than business'. But - great value, great location and I use it most times I am in Tokyo.

We stayed here for 3 nights with a room facing the Tokyo Dome and the view was magnificent. The room was of decent size and clean. However, the wifi was quite weak and connection was sometimes lost. The hotel is surround by JR, metro and subway line stations making it very convenient to travel around. There is a choice between buffet and Japanese breakfast and the food is standard. Recommended for its convenience.

You won't be disappointed. Great service and it has TGI Friday's, Denny's, 24hr McDonald's and much more in the area, if the restaurants in the hotel and room service did not meet your taste. It's right next to Tokyo Dome where Baseball and pro-wrestling events are held. The Hotel Wifi is good enough to play online games while streaming videos in the background and downloading files. The rooms are pretty big. You won't feel claustrophobic. The bathroom/shower is clean with basic amenities. Definitely enjoyed my stay there.

This hotel was very nice and clean. Had a great atmosphere throughout. On busier days they even had someone directing traffic at the elevator bay. The main complaint was there wasn't a single concierge that spoke English. Twice was given wrong advice because of language barrier that almost made me miss some of the things I wanted to do most in Tokyo. Also wanted a no smoking room because of allergies but got a smoking room for the beginning of the trip and had to suffer until they could change the room. Just be aware that you don't get what you necessarily booked.

It's not a cheap hotel and yet it's very basic. They do t even give you complimentary body lotion. The breakfast Redtaurant is super crowded and you need to wait in lines to get in. Wifi is good but other than that nothing to rave about . It's super busy and very crowded. Ask for rooms away from the lift lobby. Ask for rooms ending with 27 or 29 or 31 and facing the Tokyo dome

There for a conference nearby so location was good for me, but others may be frustrated that despite subway access it is still a little of the beaten path for tourist sights. Lots of eateries in surrounding mall as well as popular British-style pub. Buffet breakfast plentiful and good selection, but other than fantastic kiwi and croissants, was just OK. Room very big by Tokyo standards, and I like a firm bed. Very extensive range of toiletries and a bathtub! Only Japanese TV channels but internet was pretty good. Very clean rooms. The only real drawback, as others have mentioned, you can have large queues for breakfast and/or elevators, and some of the staff have limited English. The airport bus is convenient door to door, but does not run that frequently, so may not be convenient for all timewise..

We stayed recently on a group tour. We found the room comfortable and being on a high floor had lovely views of the city. We didn't really like carpet in the bathroom. We did have a huge problem with breakfast. Most times there would have been easily 100 people in the queue, and when we did get inside there seemed to be a lot of unused tables. The food was fresh and plentiful although we found the fruit section often had run out and was slow in being replaced.

Tokyo Dome hotel is located in great location, easy walking distance to local train and metro stations,it also overlooks the Baseball Stadium which links to a family styled fun park with roller coasters, water rides and family orientated restaurants.For the adults there is also large spa that is a must do for both men and women, I have not seen anything as big or as good as this. Make sure to pay for the higher level, which has colour sensory stimulation rooms, and also a full heat room for relaxation made for Himalayan rock salt.The hotel comes with several restaurant offering good quality food and choice, and the lobby is large and accommodating.Service: Reception struggles with English speaking guests, and ultimately resulted in several frustrating outcomes. This was very disappointing for a hotel of this quality. This happened on at least three occasions of me staying at the hotel, so not an isolated event.The rooms are in typical Japanese fashion compact, even for the luxury rooms. And example would be that I could not open the bar fridge completely as the bed was too close. I blocked the hole room if I wanted to iron a shirt, and the TV was at a perpendicular angle to the bed so impossible to watch from bed. NB: Beds in japan at very hard, almost bordering on a board. Make sure you request a western style matrice or you will be in for a difficult nights sleep.I found the whole experience claustrophobic, but that said this is Japan, so not uncommon.Room selection: I would make sure to ask for a room on the highest level that over looks the fun park and Baseball stadium, this will give you full views of the whole city which is spectacular both day and at night when the lights come on.Christmas time is a great time to stay here and large Christmas lighting is erected and kids love it...as well as the adults.

As the name suggests it is located next to the Tokyo Dome, an indoor baseball stadium. The precinct has good food outlets, restaurants, shops, entertainment and also an amusement park, all within walking distance of the hotel. Nearby are two stations, one is the Tokyo Metro’s Korakuen and the other is the JR Line’s Suidobashi. It is a large high rise hotel with spacious, modern and comfortable rooms suitable for business or tourists. Free wifi is available in the lobby area. The buffet breakfast was alright and of international standards. A drawback is the lift service during peak hours in the morning. Though there are a number of lifts they are usually packed and getting in is next to impossible especially if you have a suitcase. We waited for almost half an hour to squeeze into one to get down to the lobby. Would be happy to stay here again.

Centrally located and well connected with metro. Well addressed lobby with helpful staff. In spite of the size of the hotel the check-in and check-out are very smooth. One side of the hotel faces the city skyline and the other the Dome stadium and children amusement park. The convenience store is on the property as well on the JP line. There are nice restaurants on the hotel as well as in the waking distance.It appears that the management has opted to capitalize on the ever growing tourist traffic by hosting group tours, their arrival and departure makes the lobby a bit messy. In fact, it looks like the house-keeping staff is also hard pressed to accommodate group tours. The level of house keeping leaves a lot to be desired.The rooms are spacious and well appointed bath accessories, the furnishing and furniture needs attention.The breakfast spread is very good, but you need to be there in perfect time. if you land there during the group tour timings, there might be a big que and a long waiting.

This is not a business hotel. The size is quite big in Japanese standard, especially the bathroom. Location is a bit far to central tokyo like shibuya, shinjuku etc. But airport limousine just stops at the hotel and there are quite a few metro stations around the hotel. Service is good, both check in and out are fast. Not expensive at all.

I was happy with this hotel set amongst quite a quirky, fun park environment. Location for work or holiday is really convenient. Two of the Japanese restaurants at the hotel - the sushi and the tempura - are divine. Free and fast wifi.

The hotel is easily acessible from either Narita or Haneda airport by airport bus. From Haneda, it is also very easy to take Keisei train and subway (changing at Mita Station). It is next to a shopping mall with spa (onsen) facilities. The view from the hotel is great and the room size is good. There are also many attractions nearby.

This is a business/conference style hotel right in the centre of Tokyo Dome City, next to the dome and surrounded by a theme park. Rooms are clean, large and spacious, and those on the upper floors have a great view of Tokyo city. There are a number of restaurants and bars, and the Sky bar in the top floor is a great place for a drink, and to catch views over Tokyo. The hotel has good access for sight seeing, and there are bars and restaurants close by.

I stayed here for four nights and really enjoyed my stay.Positives:- Location is perfect, so close to the station and right next to the Dome. Walking distance to karaoke bars.- Views are good.- Room is fairly spacious and comfortable. Bed was comfortable but firm.- Bathrooms spacious and well appointed.- Concierge is very helpful- Breakfast options are good - "English" and Japanese in separate restaurants. The Japanese breakfast is a lot quieter and calmer and well worth a try.Negatives:- No free tea and coffee in room. Everything is on the menu and is expensive.- No "lounge area" to sit and wait for someone or have a quick chat - you have to go either inside the coffee shop or sit on one of the few hard benches that are available.But overall a good stay and I would go back again.

Stayed here on a great internet rate to attend one of the best orchid shows in the world. So, wanted too e able to come and go from the Tokyo Dome and the hotel location, just minutes away, was perfect. My room had a fabulous view of the Dome and surroundings, plenty of places to eat in the area, and several subway stations to choose from for travelling around Tokyo. Although I didn't use it, there is an airport bus directly from Narita which some travelers might find convenient, though pricey at 3100 yen.Rooms are larger than most in Japan, wifi was free and pretty strong, but the coffee in the room is of the instant variety, so if you are a coffee lover like me, wait until you are outside to purchase your morning brew.Would recommend and stay again.

Room is good enough for couple, bed is comfortable, toilet and bathroom is clean, staff are very accommodating and the beautiful view of TOKYO Dome. We enjoyed our stay in this hotel, recommended. We will comeback next time in the same hotel

This is a lovely hotel and a good location for visiting the Quilt Show in the Tokyo Dome as we were. The rooms were a fair size and the beds comfortable. We had inclusive breakfast which had an extensive menu. However the lifts in the hotel struggle to cope with the number of guests using them and we had to wait 20 minutes or more to get to restaurant or ground level. Once we walked down the emergency stairs which isn't encouraged. At the breakfast restaurant too, long queues prevailed; both to enter and then for some food items, particularly fruit and yoghurt. A shame that this lets the hotel down. The area is great for restaurants and cafes so you are never far from a meal and the station is close as well.

Arrived late at night and was warmly greeted and escorted to our room. The hotel is massive but room service finished at 12? not what one would expect from such a large hotel. The room was big and had commanding views of the city. check out is 11 am and it seems everyone checks out at this time so the line was long. Still an affordable hotel in tokyo and worth a look if you are in this area.

I've booked at Tokyo Dome mainly because of the proximity to Spa LaQua. I thought the hotel would be renovated and would give guests some kind of special deal at the Tokyo Dome and spa. Well, the hotel is pretty close but there's nothing to do with the Spa. They only give you a 500 yens coupon. Anyways, the hotel is a bit outdated, the bed is not that great. Location wise is an easy walk from suidabashi but it's also walking distance from Korakuen station. There are plenty of restaurants and convenience stores around and for the food junkers a 24 hours McDonnalds almost in front of the hotel. Another plus is the fact that you have the transportation to and from Narita and Haneda at your door step (via Limousine services, Y$3100 one-way).

Everything about this hotel is large, the scale of it, the rooms, the breakfasts - it is great for large groups but if you're looking for a romantic, cosy hotel - this probably isn't the best choice. That said, service was great, the enormous rooms and the wonderful views of Tokyo are such a treat and for business visits too, I would highly recommend this hotel.

First of all, I need to appreciate this hotel for their kind arrangement to solve my wrong booking. I mistakenly booked only one person for my whole family staying plan of three people. I realized this upon check-in. The hotel reception was kind enough to arrange a substitution room immediately and we were able to comfortably enjoy our stay. This hotel is located in just a couple of minutes of walk from Suidobashi station and very convenient whatever you do. Also, there is direct airport limousine bus departs from this hotel and it was very nice directly heading to Narita airport from hotel lobby!Its accommodation fee is reasonable and I definitely recommend this hotel and we will stay again soon in the future!

Very good hotel at reasonable price.Locaion: Great location. Next to a JR station. Next to a theme park. Also next to the tokyo dome where football matches and concerts are help there.Room: Very confortable. Room with good size. Equipped with all you need: working desk, kettle, fridge, iron board, bathroom with bath tub, fast internet speed... I really like the room very well.Room overlooking the tokyo tower was awesome!Service: Good service, staff are helpful but need to improve in english communication.Pub: Nice pub with good ambience. Overlooking the theme park and the Tokyo dome with beautiful lights at night.I'm happy to stay here again if I visit Japan in future.

The view from this hotel is quite fantastic. We had a room on the 32nd floor facing northwest. Besides the upfront view of the stadium dome and ferris wheel, the beautiful weather provided amazing views of Tokyo. The hotel is closed to the a JR line and the Toei subway line. There is a Don Quixote across the street. This store has fresh produce besides discounted prices on a lot of items. It is a tax free store, but restrictions do apply. There is a more upmarket supermarket within the dome complex. The room is a little dated with a somewhat hard bed. But the room is pretty big. However, occasionally can hear the upper floor guests making banging noises like they were playing ball in the room. During the time we were there, a popular boy band was giving a concert in the dome. There is a morning newspaper and complimentary tea bags. Bathroom has the usual amenities. The lobby is huge. Because of the many rooms it is good that there are five elevators that have awesome view of the eastern part of Tokyo. The service is good like most of Japan. Overall, a good moderately priced hotel. But, I would try to avoid the hotel during events in the dome.

I've stayed at the Tokyo Dome Hotel many times. It's in the northern part of Tokyo, adjacent to the Tokyo Dome as well as Tokyo Dome City. There are many excellent restaurants in the area (just ask the concierge for a list), including many traditional Japanese restaurants. The nearby shopping area has many excellent clothing stores. You can also take the subway from the Sudobashi station into the Ginza area for more department store shopping. The rooms are definitely cozy, but very clean with complimentary internet. Not a lot of closet space or drawers, but that's typical for a Japanese hotel. Excellent bang for the buck. Also, try the upstairs bar for a great view of Tokyo at night

review_body: Stayed three nights at Tokyo Dome hotel on holidays. Very convenient, train station is beneath hotel. Only minutes to Shinjuku and Ginza and only 20 minutes to Tokyo Disney by taxi.The rooms are huge by Japanese standard and the guests experience is first class even though they have over 1000 rooms. Everything in the room was working perfectly. There are however only japanese TV channels, no CNN or BBC which is a letdown. Check in and out was a breeze! They have 8 lifts serving the guests over 45 floors and 1008 rooms. Breakfast spread was however unchanged for three consecutive mornings. Hotel has several good jap restaurants reasonably priced for dinner and it is convenient. Room amenities can be improved with bigger TV and body lotion in the bathroom.

By chance we got this hotel as all hotels were full at the time and affordable.Very big hotel its around 3 .5 star, the bathroom very clean though not cheap for the hotel standardand.Most of the staff speak english and very helpful. Very busy hotel and the lifts are so many no problem for tourist to stay.Location is very close to the stations; just walking distances from all corners. Transportation easy to get at all times. Busy area, shops, fun rides for all ages just within the hotel, great restaurants, supermarkets etc.We have enjoyed staying for all the taxi know this hotel without opening the Google maps to show them where we want. If I will visit japan might stay again .

Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates

review_body: Truth be told, I stayed at Tokyo Dome Hotel because it was a last resort. Not sure what was going on in Tokyo, but ALL of my favorite hotels were completely sold out! Tokyo Dome Hotel is pretty close to the Tokyo Station, which is a pretty quick train ride on the Express train.The hotel had plenty of good restaurants to choose from within or close by... lots of activities to do as well.The only reason I gave the hotel 4 stars instead of 5 is because the rooms were rather lackluster and the beds were pretty uncomfortable.Service was phenomenal!

I stayed at the Tokyo Dome hotel to attend a conference but came a few days early to explore the city. The hotel is straightforward and clean if a little sparsely decorated. There are painfully few furnishings in the lobby which makes it difficult to use as a meeting point. There is also free wifi in the lobby but without a place to sit, it seems as if they didn't prefer for you to stay long. The staff were nice and happy to assist. Rooms were standard and not overly small as was feared. A highlight of this hotel are the views from the room and especially from the rooftop bar.,

The hotel is centrally located near La Qua Spa (Japanese Baths), the La Qua Mall and close to the rail and subway stations. Have stayed here on numerous occasions and the hotel has large rooms, great room service and a fantastic breakfast.

Stayed on the 33rd floor for 1 night. Room is bigger than the usual Tokyo hotel (at least you can comfortably open up 2 suitcases in the room and a walkway between the 2 beds). View is awesome, looking right at Tokyo Dome and the Ferris Wheel nearby. There are many restaurant options just across the street. Breakfast is ok though, could have more food selection.

This hotel is relatively centrally located in Tokyo. It is adequate if you want to spend your time out and about and you're just after a bed and basic amenities. Service as usual in Tokyo is very good. You will notice that almost all guests are foreign to Japan. Breakfast is large buffet style or Japanese style and is ok (not great). 5-10 minute taxi ride to the Palace and Tokyo Station. More suited to mid-range budget travellers than business. Also not far from Akihabara technology district.

Our Family of four stayed at this hotel for a week while in Tokyo. The rooms are comfortable and the view over the city fantastic, we were on the 27th floor. Breakfast every morning was delicious. Staff really are friendly and helpful. The location near the Suidobashi Station is a bonus so we could catch the metro to all the different places in Tokyo. There are also plenty of restaurants within walking distance of the hotel. The Imperial Place is an easy walk.

1. Loaction: Excellent! Only 5-minute walk way from Tokyo Dome Hotel to JR railway station and metro station. 4 stations by train to Ginze & the Emperor Garden,the center of Tokyo downtown, 7 stations to shinjuku, 2stations to Akihabara（the electrical products stores district). Metro directly to Shibuya and Omote Santo, the new Energy fashion districts (with lots of Flagship, restaurants, shops, studios and exhibition halls).2. Surrounding facilities: Very convenient! The hotel is a part of Tokyo Dome city, including a huge Tokyo Dome (baseball stadium), amusement park（open to 9.00 pm), food plaza( delicious and cheap, open to 9.00 pm), indoor children play filed, shopping mall ( with a supermarket on basement). Starbucks and 24-hour 7/11 convenient store with ATM inside. 3. Landscape: Very good! A Japanese traditional park next to the hotel with green planting and pool. Poeple can run in the park anytime. You can see the new Tokyo landmark - Tokyo Skytree in your room( over 600 meters tower) and the Dome and amusement park, different views in the daytime and at night.4. Big room with low price! A room with 28 sq. meters is only about USD $120 for one night. Common room is only no more than 15 sq.meters as the same price in Japan( Japan is famous for small guest rooms). So Tokyo Dome Hotel is Greatly recommended!

From the reception area one would think this is gonna be a lovely clean hotel, howeve; it is not!Checking in was fast and staff were very friendly. The reception area is huge looks like an airport counter.The hallway of the rooms looked ok but old with a dirty carpet. You could feel that the carpet is over used and became sticky and totally flat.First thing I noticed when I entered my room was how filthy the carpet looks, it's spotted and extremely old "eek".Second thing I noticed was the cleanliness of the room which was not up to the standard. I saw hair at the window, spots on the carpet and a piece of dirt stuck to the curtain. Of all the hotels I tried in Japan this was by far the worst. I even found the information note paper of the previous guest (housekeeping). Yet I had just checked in.It's a shameful thing that such famous hotel would be so filthy. This thing seriously needs a complete makeover.The toilet washlet is a bit old as it doesn't have some options I've seen in other hotels for example, the seat warming option or the hydraulic seat cover are missing among other options.The bed had no duvet, it was a cotton sheet covered with a cheap satin curtain like topcover. The Wi-Fi signal was awful, weak and getting disconnected every now and then.Plus points of the hotel are: location, big rooms, room view (park side), variety of restaurants nearby and 7/11 across the road.This hotel is ok for limited budget travelers. Unfortunately I booked it at the last moment cuz all 5 stars and 4 stars were fully booked.Never again.

Decent business hotel. Ok breakfast buffet, good location near Tokyo Dome. Lots of restaurants, Starbucks, train station right outside. Beds are very hard and can get annoying after 3-4 nights. Not my top choice, but adequate for short stays.

I stayed at the Dome Hotel on September 25, 2014 in Room 2517.The Dome is ultra convenient for me because it is a 5-minute walk to my Tokyo HQ. Having said that, it is close to train stations so easy to access. Not much around in terms of commercial or tourist attractions BUT the Tokyo Dome Baseball Stadium is in its backyard. That's why the hotel bursts at the seams when baseball games, concerts or other sport events are held at the stadium.The hotel is also a favorite of tour groups.Heaven forbid if you're checking-in with a tour group or the end of a game/concert...the queue for the elevators can be as bad as for the game itself! It can take up to 15-20 minutes at times.The rooms are reasonably sized. No frills. No wifi. But its comfortable and things work. Only one english tv station, too - CNN.Service is very attentive. Quite A few dining outlets on premise.Good prices ranging from ¥11,000 to ¥15,000 a night. Great value if you're just looking for a room to park yourself and your bags while you go about your business in Tokyo.Oh and, yes, the Tokyo Dome Stadium (not the hotel) is home to one of Japan's baseball teams- the Yomiuri Giants.

Stayed here for three nights. Great location ( easily accessible to both public transport, great food and shopping - including the convenience stores and supermarket) and service except for the information counter that still struggles with English. Kid friendly place too as there are lots of couples with young children staying here.

Having stayed in a few hotels in Tokyo most travellers will know that space is a luxury unless you are paying mega bucks. Tokyo Dome manages to provided adequate space, modern and clean rooms with all the basic needs for a traveller or business person. Located next to the Tokyo Dome it also provides entertainment for those seeking something different from just restaurants. With a somewhat quirky amusement park offering some decent rides, there are also some great convenience and retail shops. All the usual Starbucks, Macca's and Subway are also just around the corner. A quick Taxi ride from Tokyo Central railway will cost you around JPY1500 or catch the train for three stops at about JPY160. Those travelling will kids will find this a great place to stay with all the attractions previously mentioned. For Westerners the pillows are a little hard so try and request some alternate ones to try or use a towel to cushion the usually rice filled pillows, well at least that's how they feel for me. Staff are friendly and attentive and all speak English.

Stayed 3 nights at this hotel which ran over a weekend where there was a pop concert on at the adjoining stadium, Japanese boy band so hundreds of female spectators in attendance and also in residence at the hotel.Regardless of this the hotel was large enough to comfortably deal with the influx and while some areas were crowded sanity did prevail.Was a little concerned about lift waiting times having read other reviews which said up to 10 mins wait time was the norm found that wait time was negligible whenever we used the lifts.Clean rooms, good restaurants in the hotels, excellent buffet breakfasts, helpful staff, quick checkouts, good business centre all contributed to a good stay.Lots of restaurants, fast food outlets, cafes, shopping mall, amusement park, train stations, 7 Eleven and a Japanese garden were all within walking distance of the hotel which added to the experience, also a pick up point for the Airport Shuttle service which was very handy. Definitely would stay here again.

I have a wonderful 5 days stay at the place. It was accessible for the train support, the surroundings is good for running. Room is spacious. The morning breakfast spread is delicious also. Only issues is the Ironing board and Iron need to take from the reception.

Well located adjoining the Tokyo Dome entertainment centre and amusement park. High rise style hotel but very clean and well presented. MRT and shopping close by. Busy hotel with large crowds in the foyer at most times. Well worth it for location.

Having already stayed 10 days in Tokyo (Crown Plaza, Prince Hotel and Hilton), I wanted to discover another area and decided to stay in the Tokyo Dome Hotel, also to relax at the pool.The bathroom was not clean, the living room floor as well not. In the restaurant on the 43rd floor is a cover charge of 540 YEN applies, which is not mentioned on their webpage and I disagree that a hotel guest shall pay a cover fee for having dinner in one of their restaurants.When I wanted to go to the pool today, I found out that the pool is only opened one month a year- in August; Again nothing of this was mentioned on their webpage. Wifi is available in the room, but slow. In the restaurants no Wifi available despite it should beReally disappointed for paying a higher price and getting the worse compared to the other hotels I stayed in

Tokyo Dome Hotel is located just north of a large subway interchange station, Otemachi, and is near three different subway stations. This is a large hotel catering to those going to concerts in the Dome and also attendants of events held at Prism Hall next door. The rooms are basic but clean and breakfast is abundant and adequate. There are also many local restaurants nearby surrounding Suidobashi subway station. This is perhaps not the best hotel for sightseeing but is great if one is in Tokyo for business. Beds are not the most comfortable.

This was the third Tokyo area hotel we stayed in this week. It looks good and has a good location next to the Tokyo Dome and is close to the MRT, shopping and things to do. It is not run as efficiently as most Japanese places are. The lines to the elevator and breakfast are long mainly due to the staff over controlling things. If you don't speak Japanese, forget about ordering at the Garden Terrace in either Chinese or English because the lines and procedures are confusing. This was not a problem in shops at the other two hotels. Finally, the lines to the women's restrooms are the longest I have ever seen in any country.

I went from an airport hotel to a ryokan to a basic hotel to Tokyo Dome Hotel. I believe I've had a pretty well rounded experience with hotels in Japan at this point. This was the most expensive out of the 4 hotels during my stay, $200+ US Dollars a night. I was here for a good 3 nights. The amenities, staff, and location were all superb. On my next visit, I would not hesitate to book with this hotel again. It was a pleasure staying here.Cons:-Laundry was super expensive, although extremely well taken care of-Elevators were always in high demand. I never waited too long for one. My issue is with the elevator making pit stops on basically every floor until I get off. This probably isn't an issue the hotel can work on thoughPros:-Very close to Suidobashi station for both the JR and Toei lines-Rooms were cleaned and towels replaced daily-Spacious standard double room-Large bathroom, which I love-Free in-room wifi. I was worried about this prior to my check-in after reading older reviews. Seems the hotel have fixed the wifi issue. Now there's free wifi for EVERYONE YAY!!!! It's also fast-Great laundry service-Souvenir shop with a manicure station inside located a floor above lobby-Lovely wide open lobby-All bathroom toiletries available-Front desk kindly accepted my delivered luggage and brought it up to my room upon my request-Hotel located next to amusement park-Hotel location offers a walkable distance to Akihabara-Kind and helpful staff-Great in-room view even from the 18th fl-Fully stocked mini-fridge-There are restaurants located within the hotel

Great hotel. Right in the middle of everything. Room was bigger than other hotels I've stayed at in Tokyo. Check in was simple and easy. Took only about 5 minutes. Glass elevators offered great views of Tokyo Dome City. Lots to do outside of the hotel we walked around for a few hours watching people on the rides at the midway and did some people watching at the Tokyo Dome as a Baseball game let out.The bed was low to the floor and hard. One of the hardest beds I've ever slept on. Wasnt neccesarily a bad nights sleep (or maybe I was just really tired after a long flight). Bathroom was big. There was a desk with a LAN internet connection that was pretty fast No wifi but that worked for me. I got what I think was a pretty good deal on Agoda.com for $120 usd for the one night. Train station was close by and we even took the train to Tokyo Disney which we were told would take about 70min but only took us about 45 minutes to get there. Not a bad ride at all.Arrived into Narita then caught the Airport limo bus which was like $35-40 per person USD and took about 1hr. The next day we flew out out Haneda Limo Bus was just $25 USD there.

My teenage son and I have been using and loving this hotel since he was a toddler. There are many shops and restaurants, and an amusement park in the Tokyo Dome City and nearby. We usually go to a convenience store across the street, or a grocery store in LaQua area (5 mins walk) for food since eating out all the time gets pretty pricey. Foods at convenient stores are pretty good!The hotel is in a very, very convenient location. There are JR/subway stations nearby, and it's easy to get around everywhere in Tokyo. There are tour buses picking you up at this hotel.The staffs are extremely polite.

Well situated next to both subway station and JR line. The hotel offers rooms with good space and high standard. The service is quick and very efficient. If possible, get a room high up in the building. You will get an excellent view of Tokyo!

Let’s be clear on one thing. The location of this hotel is REALLY SUPERB if you are a baseball fan because of the Tokyo Dome where they host baseball matches on matchday.If not, it is actually few minutes walk to nearest train station and not very well inter-link in my opinion.Hotel lobby looks decent, rooms seems slightly better too, although non smoking rooms seems to have a stench when I checked in as well which doesn’t really please me.Blanket of the room is not of top quality, seems thin to keep myself warm at times and bed is slightly harder than I would prefer.Other than that, cleanliness is kept and the toilet, though seems a little old, is decent for me.I had the opportunity to ordered the room service and I must say the food is merely so so, especially with the price I am paying, it really doesn’t justify.

Loved the glass elevator going up and down, with a view of Tokyo dome at night.Room was big, perfectly comfortable and there was both JR line and tokyo metro within 5 mins walking distance.However no wireless wifi in rooms-that was the only flaw. We had to go down to the lobby which we really didn't want to do after a long day.

I stayed at Tokyo Dome for two nights to attend an event at a nearby university. The hotel was easily accessible by JR Line train or Toei Line subway. But there is no elevator/escalator in the JR station so keep it in mind when traveling with heavy luggage. The room was spotless, staff helpful although spoke limited English. Wifi in the room was not free but you can rent an adaptor and router for a reasonable price. Adjacent to the hotel is the Tokyo Dome Park, where there was a hawker center where we could eat Japanese food. There is much green in the area and in the spring dotted with cherry blossoms.

Have visited the Tokyo Dome hotel quite regularly, is good accessible, good value hotel. Quite a few in hotel restaurants, even more very close by. You will have to experience this yourselves.I have not been sorry having to stay here.

I stayed here for a recent business trip within Tokyo. The hotel is located right next to the Super Dome where the Tokyo Tigers (baseball) team plays. Literally, walk outside of the hotel and you can reach the Dome. The hotel has a variety of restaurants and has both traditional Japanese and Western foods. The room was clean and adequate. The hotel has free public wifi in the lobby, but you can request to pay for wifi and they will be happy to accommodate you. Just ask for it when you check in or go to guest services. I tried their breakfast buffet several times. It has a variety of food, but if you want a Western Style Breakfast, their is a McDonalds across the street. I did enjoy their Japanese Breakfast which was quite delicious! I also had dinner at their Japanese Restaurant that served a high quality tempura dinner. Absolutely fantastic!The staff is very polite and are willing to help in any way. The Hotel is within walking distance to the public train systems and several nearby fast food chainsSomething to note: if you have tattoos, you are not allowed in the swimming pool area. Also, the hotel does not have a gym facility.

review_body: We just stayed this week for five nights as a base for our japan holiday, this hotel was great value for a midrange priced hotel, paid around $960 AUD for five nights. Should really be a five star hotel, staff could not have been friendlier, they brought our luggage to the room within minutes and changed us to non smoking room on 37th floor for no cost. Room was super clean and serviced daily with the comfiest doona ever!!Bathroom had a bath, and great toiletries including razor.Laundry service was fantastic although expensive but clothes came back wrapped as if they had been store bought.Super close to Suidobashi station on JR LINE, and a supermarket, bars and restaurants are within walking distance.Overall, five star stay!! Thanks Tokyo Dome.

Just stayed here for 5 nights on business. The rooms are large and clean, with free wired internet (WIFI is an extra). Slight feeling of being a little dated, but the room was comfortable. TV only had one English language channel (CNN) but there is plenty to go out and see!Just to the South, under the railway line is a host of small streets with some great Japanese restaurants, not too expensive either.Connection wise you can get the Airport Limousine bus here directly, simple and not expensive, and it is well connected with 3 metro lines and a train station all within a short walk of the hotel.The Tokyo Dome itself is quiet impressive, and I can imagine that on a big game day the place is packed, and so would the hotel be. That said I read reports of ques for lifts, but didn't see that once in 5 days.

We stayed here for 2 nights on the final leg of our journey in Japan, it was just what the doctor ordered! The hotel is huge, clean and the rooms are a great size, biggest we stayed in all trip. The beds were comfy, the shower and bathroom were fantastic and the room overall was spotless! The only downfall would be that you have to pay for wi-fi and the mini bar prices are a bit steep. As we wernt flying out until the evening, we asked for a late check out, we were advised that this would cost us half a days room rate for the privlage- NO Thanks! The plug socket in our room didnt work, so i asked the front desk if they could charge my tablet whilst i am out sightseeing, after 8 hours out i got back to an empty battery on my tablet, when i asked again for them to please charge it for an hour before i left for the airport, they took my tablet out the back and again didnt plug it in- not sure weather it was the language barrier or they just didnt care to listen to my requests. All in all the location is great for JR lines etc and there are plenty of nice places to eat around the hotel. Overall it was a nice hotel to end a two week trip visiting Japan. I would reccomend requesting a room

I stayed there with my family and kids. Great surroundings with outdoor themed park, amusement center for kids, lots of convinience stores just a walk away. Can borrow for a free converter for your gadgets.Hotel staffs all friendly and helpfull. Rooms quite big and everything looks tidy and clean.

Stayed for the McCartney concert (Nov. 2013) and honestly wasn't expecting much other than the location. However, the stay was well worth the money. The guest room was bigger than expected (for a room in Tokyo) and had all the iconic view from the room. I had problem with the wi-fi but the LAN cable was provided in the room so no problem there. Had the choice between Western-style breakfast buffet or Japanese-style breakfast and we chose the latter. Found out later that the Japanese restaurant was a well-established Kyoto restaurant and thought got a great deal: )

I see a few bad reviews about this hotel, me and my wife stayed here for three nights, and our experience has been really very good! Wifi as few says is an issue, i dont think so, you can ask for a wifi device which is chargeable 300 yen for whole of your stay and just plug in your room, excellent 24 hrs video stremable speed!!!Great location, courteseous people as all over Japan, good breakfast, reaaly i didnt find any negatives...Tall high building if you like view from the top!

I stayed in Tokyo Dome Hotel on May 11~17,and booked from a Japanese website(ikyu.com - according to my friend,this website usually has good price for business hotels.I had Google Chrome translate to help me get through it .) Pros：●Room size reaches my expectation and feel comfortable.I think the big window with 36th-floor-high-magnificent view also helps to enlarge the feel of room size.●Bathroom size and layout made me happy.I am 5 ft 8 tall and feel easy in the bathroom.Especially there is a magic auto fan inside the TOTO toilet which makes any unpleasant smell disappear very quick.If you stay with a friend,this kind of technology really helps.●Clean and Quiet room.It's so quiet in room and made me think we were the only guests on 36th floor until I saw they cleaned other rooms in the morning.●Location is convenient. We enjoyed the nearby shopping mall a lot (girls u know).There are also four Metro lines around.Cons：●No Wifi in room：But I got a Pocket WIFI so ok for me.Others：●Have seen other reviews about long waits for elevator, but never happened to us.Maybe because we avoided busy hour (ex: 8~9am,8~9pm)?●Sum Up：This hotel was worth the money we paid. We like the 7-days stay in this hotel, will come back.

Hotel was covered by a business partner so not sure about value. The hotel itself was very nice, several restaurants inside the hotel, but they are as good as usual hotel restaurants. I saw other reviewers complain about wifi, but if you ask the front desk, they'll give you an in-room wifi adaptor for 300 yen.The major big con for me was the hotel location. It was very difficult to find any good restaurants that are walkable, and the ones that were around were very odd restaurants around the Tokyo Dome. Also the whole vibe if the area wasn't very exciting at all. I stayed in this hotel during my first 4 days in Tokyo, then moved to a hotel in Roppongi (which I wish I had stayed in Roppongi the whole time).

Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: The best thing about this hotel is the location. The rooms are a tad bigger than the Tokyo average, which is good, but not nearly big enough to justify the price. The rooms are about $170 and above. This does not include breakfast. By comparison, a Toyoko Inn or Dormy Inn will cost about $90-100, and feed you breakfast. As I mentioned, the room was a decent size, but it had some strange stains on the carpet and chair. The lines for check-in/out are ridiculous -- I think I waited at least 10-15 minutes. The wait for the elevator was equally long, sometimes as long as 10 minutes. None of these things are huge complaints, but I just expect more for this kind of money. For the $200 range, you can do better.Postitive: Great location; amazing view; larger than average room; nice bathroom.Negative: Long waits; expensive price; no breakfast.Average: Bed softness; lobby is confusing; it's kind of hard to find the right entrance.

The room is relatively spacious for a Tokyo hotel, the amenities are OK (even though the coffee is not free), but it is not so convenient for a business traveler who requires a wifi connection not only for the computer (LAN is available) but also for using tablet and smartphone devices.

Comfortable large hotel, stayed two nights in late March on an organised tour. The arrival of our 26 strong group was delayed because rooms were not ready. After flight via Singapore this was disappointing. The buffet food was quite good but a lot of the hot selections were not hot, this was for an evening buffet meal and for both breakfasts.

ProsGreat ServiceLarge Room SpaceGood LocationConsNO Wifi accessible from room. All guest need to hog the seats in the lounge to access Wifi.First night when call the front desk, they mentioned they do not have wifi. Second day, try my luck to ask for Wifi. Turn out they do but accessible at the lounge only.Long Queue to catch the lift. There are always long queue of guests trying to use the lift.Hard bed and two small pillow. The bed was too hard for my liking and the pillow is to flat and small. They should consider providing the guest a proper bed considering the amount of money to pay per night in this hotel.No seat warmer in the toilet. I usually don't use seat warmer in the toilet. But, since we are in Tokyo, city of new technology. It is quite disappointing that they don't provide seat warmer. Even, public toilet do provide seat warmer.

As we all know we only appreciate things when they are not there anymore. This hotel has nothing, so its easier to say what is there: A bed, TV with 5 Japanese Channels, Bar of soap, Toilet paper and 2 towels. That pretty much sums it up. No WiFi as mentioned a few times here. No Gym. This is one of these massive event hotels where service does not count because people will be coming in anyway when there is an event. You have to queue up to check in and out. You have to queue up to wait for a taxi in the morning. Unfortunately I had no choice as all other hotels were totally booked out. Will not come again. It is clean though and functional. Rooms are noisy. You can hear your neighbor.

Stayed here as it was close to my office and the other hotels were full. I'm not sure how many stars this place has but it is pretty ordinary. I stayed on the 'excellence' floor but compared to other parts of Asia, it was far from excellent. Super strict with check in and check out time unless you pay extra. The lady wanted $20 for me to check in at 3.15pm instead of 4pm????????Good location though and nothing to complain about, but no WOW factor!!

I traveled to Tokyo to see the Rolling Stones at the Tokyo Dome on 26 February and wanted a hotel that was close to the concert venue. I stayed for three nights at the Tokyo Dome Hotel, could not have been any closer to the concert and was very satisfied with my stay.First, I found the bus limousine service between Narita and the Tokyo Dome Hotel to be very easy and very efficient. The hotel does a great job in the morning getting you on the bus. My non-smoking room was on the thirty-sixth floor and was very nice. I looked down on the Dome. My room was comfortable, nicely furnished, well maintained and the bed and pillows were not quite as firm as I have regularly found throughout Asia. I had no noise problems. There was a small refrigerator with a min-bar, a safe, a humidifier, an abundant supply of the common amenities found in the bathroom and there was even a scale in the bathroom. There was a kettle in the room but if you used their coffee you had to pay for the coffee. Apparently, the tea was free.The breakfast buffet offered a standard variety of western and Asian foods and it worked for me (the coffee was decent). If you want western branded places to eat they are close by. Inside the hotel there is a Sizzler’s with a good salad bar. And, if you leave the front of the hotel and make a left there is a 7-11 and Starbucks a short walk away. A short distance to the right of the hotel there is a Denny’s. And, if you go out the front and cross the street, just to your left is a McDonald’s. Also, if you go out the front and make a left and then go to the first main intersection and make a right, after you cross the street you will pass a train station and if you keep walking you will find a very nice business district with lots of small Japanese restaurants. If you go out the back of the hotel and keep the Dome on your left and walk towards the roller coaster, you will see a walking bridge that will take you to a shopping mall that also has many places to eat. I preferred the hotel’s bar on the sixth floor (go during happy hour) to the stand-up bar and restaurant on the forty-third floor. I found the staff at the hotel to be very pleasant and helpful. And, although the Tokyo Dome is not the greatest venue the Stones were in excellent form and I really enjoyed the concert.

Very clean and spacious by Tokyo standards. Close to the subways and amusement park. We did not find the night life in the area to be that much fun but for the price of the hotel you can eaily take a subway ride to any where in Tokyo.

Everything ,except for the wait for the lifts , was excellent , the location , service , room facilities were perfect for relaxed business trip to Tokyo with plenty of transport options readily available and a nice selection of local restaurants and spa & well being services close by to relieve you from any jet lag or work related stresses

The hotel is huge and the view from the top is one of the best in Tokyo. Rooms are big for Japanese hotels standards, clean and modern. The rate was also very reasonable, the only thing that bothered me was that there is no wifi in the rooms (only LAN). You can rent a router for 300 JPY, but they will have to do something about it. Great spot to start form when discovering Tokyo.

My wife and I stayed here because my wife wanted to get to an exhibition at the Tokyo dome. It was certainly convenient for that but otherwise for me the hotel had little to recommend it. We had booked and paid for a higher floor room but as we wanted to check in early after a 12 hour flight (sorry no rooms - can we pay for one - yes we have rooms...) then we ended up paying extra AND getting a lower floor. The bed was solid and poor, the room was very small and had poor sound-proofing. The view was ok (it is much better on a high floor) but couldn't always be seen because the condensation on the window was so bad. The breakfast wasn't great either. However the location is good (even if you don't need just the Tokyo Dome) with good JR and subway access. And the staff at the information desk were unfailingly helpful, smiling and delightful.

I stayed here for a work conference for 5 days. It is a nice hotel with beautiful view of the city BUT for a hotel of this calibre, I would expect that Wifi is accessible from my room. I had to go down to the lobby to join other guests crowding in the lobby just to access the precious wi-fi.The hotel's location is superb, 3 mins walk from Starbucks so you can actually have your coffee or breakfast without having to spend a lot in the hotel's breakfast buffet. This is very close to several subway stations and minutes walk from shopping area. It's also worth mentioning that the rooms were generally spacious. This is an OK hotel.

I have stayed at the Toyko Dome every year for the last 13 years. Nice location. Easy access to JR line and the subway. The service is good but has gone down in the past few years. The rooms are clean with plenty of amenities. They have an information desk with English speaking girls that are very helpful if you need to get from point A to point B. You should know where you are going first!When making reservations be to sure to ask for non-smoking! You have to make a point of it or you will be stuck on a smoking floor. Leaving and receiving messages at the front desk can be trying at best.Overall nice stay. I will stay again.A bus from the airport will take you to the hotel. A bus will take you back to the airport. Be sure to reserve a seat for the bus going back to the airport.

staying here betw. dec 26 and 31. opted for this hotel because of location and price over the Chinzanso hotel (which prides itself in customer service). What a mistake. I don't know it's because of peak time betw. Xmas and the New Year, when you are traveling you want to feel welcomed. I hope my experience was not typical, but it was very negative.Check In: no smile (not sure it's a culture thing), rushed through my checkin despite no one on the line (7pm). I requested high floor and king bed. But gave me a low floor / double bed and smoking room. I understand it depends on availability but at least let me know. The smoke smell was terrible. I called to exchanged the room, and a guy said "ooh, smoking room is okay" and I insisted and then he mumbled something and hung up (first time I was ever hung up by a hotel staff). Well, the ladies who took my luggage and brought me to the new room (24 floors higher now) were very pleasant (only high point). Next day I went to guest service or conceirge, the lady pretended to look for things in the drawer for a half minute as I stood in front of her, then looked at me without saying anything and gave me a "what do you want" look. I was going to ask for nearby info and then just ask for a local map. She took out a map and slided it over the desk to me (still without saying a word). I am equally offended and bewildered by this experience at the Tokyo Dome Hotel, and in Japan of all places. I hope this is an unique instance. But 3 out of 4 encounters turned to be extremely unpleasant and each time I started with Hi and a smile. Worse customer attitude than the NYC DMV!!!

review_body: Conveniently connected to a metro station, shopping mall, amusement park and the Tokyo Dome Stadium, this hotel is perfect for business or vacation with young kids. Rooms are generously spacious by local standards and some have good views of the Dome. The glass elevators serving the guest rooms offer great view of the city skyline. Breakfast options are great too where you can go for the usual intercontinental spread or the traditional local set.

love the hotel - staff was great. enjoyed the location to everything. I would stay here again. The breakfast was awesome each day. Starbucks was just outside the hotel so that was a great benefit for us North American Coffee drinkers.

Currently at this hotel. It is great, clean and surprisingly large rooms. On the 25th floor and the view is amazing. I brought with me a wifi extender so i have wifi in my room. Simply plugged into the lan connection and happy days. I would recommend here to all

I have been at this hotel during my last business trip in Japan and I haven’t had any problems with service or facilities. Hotel has a great location with excellent direct connection to JR and Metro Stations. The very nice lobby, the eight elevators (!), the cleanliness, the wonderful views, the spacious rooms makes this hotel very high quality. On the bad side: there is no direct wi-fi in the room, only a LAN cable, but you can rent a router for a very small price (300 Yen); breakfast in the restaurant at 3rd floor is not what you expect for price, but you can have a good and cheap breakfast in the Starbuck’s just outside the hotel.The room rates are not cheap, however for Tokyo standards they are not so expensive; I would say average value for money. The service is not perfect but still very fine. The same can be said for the whole hotel in general. I would go back again at Tokyo Dome Hotel.

when i come to this hotel, this hotel is very Crowded.amazing. i only sleep for 1 night herethis hotel had 8 elevator, with 2 types level the breakfast is quite good, the room is Good, my room view is Good.the hotel is near to TOKYO DOME. this hotel so Crowd, when i check out at 7.00 AM this hotel Lobby is Crowd too.OMG! i wish i have one hotel like THIS! always crowded.

Tokyo Dome is spectacular, especially on the twentienh floor during an earthquake, the entire building sways backwards and forwards and the earth feels like it is moving, quite normal to the Japanese who were unperturbed.On a practical note the hotel has spectacular views and a trip up to the bar on the forty fifty floor is worth the cover charge to enjoy the lights of Toyko spread out beneath. The hotel alsoserves western breakfasts, (very welcome), has free WI FI in the lobby and very comfortable rooms. Definitely recommend it for a Toyko stay

Your room is spacious (Japan standard of course). The staff is very helpful. Just next to Tokyo Dome, you might come across to Giants fans if there's game. Many restaurants nearby, from French, Italian, Chinese and Japanese food. There's theme park as well. And souvenir shops... And just around the corner you can find starbucks.

What can I say. The hotel is overrated the rooms are clean but nothing special. For international clients there is not many English speaking people. Being a modern country you would expect to have WiFi in every room, not here. You have to request a WiFi modem to be put in your room, if there are any remaining. I found better services in a smaller town hotel.

Maybe I was lucky, however I have been at this hotel twice and have never had any problems with service or facilities. The room rates are not cheap, however for Tokyo they are not horribly expensive, I would say average value for money. On the good side for me there are the breakfast buffet, the great location with several things to see & do within walking distance and good direct connection to Tokyo Station, the very nice lobby, the cleanliness, the views, the spacious rooms (although a bit dated at times) for Tokyo standards. On the bad side: there is no wi-fi in the room, only a LAN cable, which in my opinion is not fine for a hotel of this level in central Tokyo (they seriously have to improve it), the beds are quite hard although for my taste they are still reasonable, the hateful smoking rooms (non-smokers, stay away!). The service is not perfect but it is fine. The same can be said for the whole hotel in general. I would go back a third time.

Big name hotel, but vastly overrated. Poor value for money. Common areas (lobby/breakfast/reception rooms) really nice, good view from higher floors, but rooms are old and worn down for the class of hotel its supposed to be. Bed is really hard and uncomfortable, back hurt after two days. TV small, not great. Hallways and room have an odd smell to them, and smoking rooms unbearable. Location isn't great--good access to subway/JR line but not much within walking distance. Exceptionally annoying was is no wifi in the guest rooms (hello!?!), so if you have a computer with no ethernet port you can only use the net in the lobby. Every hotel in Asia has wi-fi, even dumpy love hotels. Brought it up to the front desk, who kind of aloofly just said 'sorry we're working on it'. Hotel has adapters but they make you pay for them. Last straw was had to leave early on a bus for Airport, got to breakfast (a buffet, mind you), and the line was so long that my kid and I couldn't eat breakfast. When presented with this, the front just said "sorry" and brushed it off. Had to barge into the breakfast buffet in order get my 2 1/2 year old kid food before an hour long bus ride to Narita. Was bad enough, but the aloof nature of the service at the front desk kind of put it over the top. Summary: Not the worst hotel on earth (lobby is great) but mediocre service, nowhere near worth the money.

I'm currently at this hotel now for one night after a 2+ week stay mainly in Tokyo and Osaka areas. This is the most expensive hotel I've stayed at with my daughter, but I thought for our last night, it would be worth spending a little extra for a few extra comforts before a long flight home.Well boy was I wrong...First impressions were great, there's a beautiful lobby, impressive glass elevators that show off the immaculate Tokyo Dome area, check in was good - they promptly took our luggage and delivered it quickly to us in our room.The rooms are a good size for Japan, but particularly Tokyo standards. But that's where the good news stops. The beds, whilst not totally uncomfortable are really quite hard - I do understand some people like firm beds, but of the 4 hotels we've stayed at, these are definitely the hardest. The TV is small for a hotel of this 'class', and the rooms are overall bland and lack character. The walls also seem to be made of paper, you can hear lots of banging, tapping, etc. from other rooms.I did get a reasonable rate on this room, so would have given it more than 1 star if it hadn't taken 3 hours to connect to the internet.The website advertises free wireless LAN and broadband. I have my laptop with me - I was quite happy to connect to the internet with the LAN cable provided in the room, which I did for the first several hours (I was in and out of the room of course). But then it stopped working. I contacted front desk, they sent up a staff member to assist, and another to assist - we just couldn't get connected to the internet again via the cable.I asked for wireless, no they couldn't help me. They apologised but said there was nothing they could do. NOT GOOD ENOUGH! After fiddling around for another 1.5 hours (I really needed the internet!), I called front desk again and suddenly they were able to send someone up with wireless LAN - at a cost of 300 yen!! Now I know this is only a small charge - I was more than prepared to pay it when I first contacted front desk about my internet connection problems - but after several hours I was fed up! I do not understand why when I asked and asked, this wasn't provided earlier!Anyhow, the gentleman who connected me to the internet (in the end) advised it was complimentary, but this hotel is going to have to improve its service standards. This is not how I intended my last night in Tokyo to be. I was preparing to wind down with a nice glass of wine and take in a good view of the wonderful Tokyo city.English is overall good at this hotel so there is no excuse to keep a guest waiting 3 hours to be connected to the internet when wireless LAN is available.

Stayed at the Tokyo Dome Hotel for almost 10 days, whereof half of the time was for business.The hotel is placed right next to a large funfair, which on my arrival, thought would be a night mare. It turned out that it was to no bother at all.The service is excellent all the way and throughout to the restaurants, tea bar, and cocktail bar (bar 2000).The hotel has a good variety of restaurants, a bit for everybody and the tea bar serves good cream cakes and tea.The bar 2000 is located on the 6th floor and did to my surprise shake a good cocktail.The rooms are good and clean, the air conditioner is quiet, but there is no Wi-Fi, only the old fashion cable.

One of the best things about staying at the Tokyo Dome Hotel is that it is part of a major, no-kidding landmark, the Tokyo Dome, so that no matter where you're coming from, where you've gone or how much sake you've imbibed, any taxi driver in Tokyo can figure out where you want to go. You'll never worry about not finding your way back to your hotel. It is also within walking distance to one of Tokyo's best restaurant districts, and there are two different train stations/train lines within a stone's throw of the hotel. It is clean, efficient, and just enough English is spoken that you'll not have any real challenges in staying here. On the downsize, the rooms are very typical Tokyo, which is to say they are very small and sparsely furnished with minimal, IKEA-esque furnishings . . . $300 bucks worth of cheap furniture, and a $3,000 Droid toilet that will warm, wash, scrub, shower, and blow-dry your nether regions! I had a very good stay here, but can only give the hotel three stars because (a) the beds are horrible, essentially a box spring and mattress pad, minus the actual mattress, yielding very poor sleep, and (b) the in-room internet is pretty lame considering you're in the land of consumer electronics - your computer is on a very short leash in the form of a small ethernet cable, no wi-fi to be had. apparently there is wi fi in the lobby, but it is an upcharge and not easy to figure out. One other point on the +plus+ side of the ledge, the Tokyo Dome was very reasonably priced - not something you ever expect to find in Tokyo!

We stayed at this hotel as the conference we were attending had put up all its guests here.The hotel is part of a complex which also includes a baseball stadium and across the road from an interesting shopping complex which incorporates a big dipper and fun fair. Quite different from the smaller hotels we would normally stay at but obviously aimed at conferences and business people. Our room on the 31st floor had the most amazing views.Location wise its within walking distance of the royal palace, and an interesting Japanese garden just around the corner where the mosquitos are waiting for you. There are lots of cheap eating places close by and lots of Japanese families with small children at the weekend coming to use the facilities of the fun fair.The hotel rooms were a good size. Free Wi-Fi is only available in the reception area, if you want Wi-Fi in your room you have to pay for it. If you have a lap top then you can access the internet via cable for free. The staff are extremely helpful and one lady in particular went to great extreme to sort our transport problem on what was a public holiday - what a star. The only downside is the inflexible approach to checking in. Jet lagged guests who have been arriving all morning/early afternoon are waiting in the reception area then at the appointed time suddenly everyone gets up and rushes over to the desk to check in. Other reviewers found the bed uncomfortable, but I thought they were just right, but then I like a firm mattress. Bathrooms had everything you needed with everything from hairbrush, toothbrush etc. An iron would have been useful, but then I am sure if I had asked for one it would have been provided.Would certainly stay here again.

I spent one night here have last been here 6 years ago. Not much changed with the usual high level of service and comfort. Views from the 43 floor was the main reason for returning as this is one of the "must see" sites of the world - particularly at night! Excellent shuttle bus service tot he Narita Airport at Y3,000.

What I love about this hotel:1. Great location. It is within Tokyo Dome complex, along with a mall, a station (so we can get around easily)2. Nice facility. Huge lobby, big rooms (compared to other hotels in Japan)3. Wide selection of food for breakfast. I particularly love their udon.They just need to have free wifi in the rooms, then they'd be perfect. So far, it's a free high speed internet, but not wireless..

I stayed at this hotel about a week. It was probably one of the best hotels that I ever stayed at in Japan, particularly given the price I was charged. The room was clearly the largest hotel room I have ever had in a Japanese hotel. There was no iron and iron board in the room, but when were promptly brought to my room on request. The internet was fast (ethernet connection only, but with the possibility to share a wifi network with the mobile devices). The rooms are also quiet, have a nice table for work. There are many restaurants around the hotel, some of them with Western menus, which may be handy if you do not want to exclusively eat Japanese (or Asian) food. At the Tokyo Dome there is also a food court, which provides a selection of Asian cuisines. I don't speak Japanese, and this neighborhood I had no problems getting good meals despite the language barrier. Definitely a good location to explore the rest of Tokyo.One nice thing about the hotel is that it is also just next to a subway station, which makes it very accessible. I also had to shorten my stay by one day, which I announced upon check-in, and that was changed without extra charge (I have also made the opposite experience in Japan). I would definitely stay here again.

Service was good, the rooms were clean, great location, great view from the room, even better view from the restaurant at the top.As others have said, no wi-fi in the rooms so you have to go to the lobby if you didn't bring something that has an Ethernet port. This kind of sucks but is not the end of the world.The big downer was the beds.. those things were crap! Probably among the worst hotel beds I've ever slept in.. multi-way tie for that. I was able to sleep OK-ish for the whole nights, but woke up with sore neck/back. Fix the beds and I'd give it a better overall rating.

This hotel was clean, spacious and very central in Tokyo. The wifi was only working in the lobby when I stayed. The buffet breakfast was more than adequate, and the staff were very helpful. The room and bathroom were very large.

It is a very large hotel and well managed. Very good service from front info desk to other staff. I have no problem of speaking English there. The airport limo bus takes you direct to the hotel. 2 minutes walk to JR and metro station. It is clean and next to lots of activities and shops.Somehow the elevators in this hotel are very slow. The bed is not that comfortable.

I met my husband in Japan at the end of his business trip and he was staying at the Tokyo Dome Hotel. It is large, and easy to find. The room was actually fairly large (for Japanese standards) was clean, and had everything needed for a short stay. There was complimentary in-room internet, but not free wifi. Even though there is a lot to do around the Dome complex, we didn't really check any of it out. We didn't eat any meals, choosing to find restaurants on our own. There were a few cool bars around the area, and 2 Starbucks in the complex.While it was fine, I would probably not choose to stay again, as it felt farther away from the things we wanted to see/do in Tokyo and was just alright.

I did not stay here, but was there in my friend's room and I experienced how wonderful and efficient their service is. My friend had requested for a non-smoking room but when we entered the room... It was reeking of cigeratte smell, so she made a call to the reception to ask why and they realized they had given her a room on the smoking level, and gave her a free upgrade to a bigger room on the non-smoking level. Service was prompt and efficient.The room was comfy and big for Japanese standards. Would consider staying at this hotel in the future. ^^

We have all heard that Japan is one of its kind and that Tokyo is a World City with no parallel. I was pleasantly surprised to understand what that truly meant. The cultural feel to the hotel and its environs is unique. The location is good with proximity to entertainment and activity zones. There are plentiful choices for dining close to the hotel. The rooms are compact and with adequate facilities for a business traveler. I took a Non-Smoking room which had a sports motif in the most ingenuous of places, including crockery. Elegant design is another hidden gem that one can catch in various locations within the hotel. The restaurant is expansive and carries various types of cuisine. There is a LAN cable for Internet in the room. Probably the in-room dining menu could be improved since it practically has no options for vegetarians. The absence of a fitness center is another drawback. Two suggestions that I would like to make - always carry cash since a lot of restaurants around the hotel do not accept credit cards and do keep 15 - 20 minutes of buffer time to catch a taxi in the morning.

I usually stay at Tokyo Dome Hotel when visiting Tokyo University. About $100/night. The rooms are clean but small. Bed is comfortable. Nice desk with power outlet (not a given at some hotels). Free in-room internet. Good location. Short walk to Grand Palace for jogging. 20 min walk or one subway stop to Tokyo University. Three stops to Ueno station. Narita bus goes directly to the hotel, takes about one hour.Downside: Elevators can be slow. No hotel gym, although there is a big gym nearby on the other side of the stadium, and the hotel has a discount. About $20.

This hotel is a good place to stay. friendly atmosphere and nice rooms with a nice view.Breakfast is always a little busy, but quality of the buffet is good. Power sockets are difficult to find in the room and at inconvenient places, so charging PC and telephone is not made easy.Very handy is the on of button ofr the airco next to you bed, so incase it gets to cold or warm in the room you can easily swtich on/off the airco, so you don't need to get out of your bed during the night.

Staff were very friendly & helpful, rooms were always spotlessly clean. Very good location for our 2 children with plenty of things to do, close to train station & 7 eleven underneath. Rooms were a good size compared to other Japanese Hotels, we were there for a week & this was fine for the 4 of us. Wi-fi is only 300 yen for your entire stay & we had no problems at all with it.Will definately stay here again.

The hotel is a good business hotel - it's clean, in a convenient location. The bed is not that great, and the rooms are a little worn/dated. I would stay here again for business, but not holiday. The breakfast is decent, good variety.The lifts take *forever*, make sure you allow enough time to depart your floor, as well as wait in line to get to your floor (depending on time of day)
