review_body: Stayed one night (booked by travel agent).Pros:- Ok location- Decent size (for Japan) room and bathroom- Very clean- Usual amenities, although there is a charge for making coffee in the room- Complimentary high speed wired internet in roomCons:- Elevators are small and too few, generating lines during peak hours- Front desk staff speaks poor English- Hefty charge for WiFi in room- No gym. To use a nearby gym there is a charge of 2,100 yen per person per visit and opening hours are limited (no evening hours)- Breakfast was ok, mostly Japanese with a very limited selection of western items

We stayed here for 1 night to see a Tokyo Giants game.Pro's:1) Room was nice and medium size 2) AC was quiet and efficent3) Bed was not super hard which can be an issue in Japan as they tend to be very hard mattresses.4) Great location for the game and also for the nearby JR trains.Con's:1) Not enought elevators (or at least in service?) for a hotel this large. Seemed like I would wait a long time to get down from the 37th floor.2) Went and had a late lunch at 43rd floor. Host was confused about lunch being served and we were seated in front of a window with a nice view but they had built this large wooden pattern on the window that partially blocked the view.3) The food at the cafe was mediocre and drinks were way overpriced. 670 yen for a coke!4) One English channel (BBC news)

It is one of the most elegant hotels in Tokyo, close to many shops and the sports stadium in Tokyo. Very clean, many shops and security and advisors are everywhere to help you. The rooms are bigger than most other Japanes hotels and the variety of food is overwhelming. Price is a little pricey, but worth it.

The hotel is nice, clean. I did not find it tourist friendly.It was a struggle to be understood , no to many english speaking employees.Is not even 1 english channel, usually you can watch BBC World ,wii is very slow to.Is no complementary coffee in the room, even the coffee is there you will be charged 200 Y. Nice new shopping complex .

Stayed here for a recent conference, the hotel was well located to where we were conferencing and that was a positive thing. Pros* very clean* every staff member very friendly* ok location* reasonably pricedcons*early check in was 150% of the room rate per night (outrageous)* extra cost for wireless internet in room* staff at check in spoke very poor english* no english language television channels*anything we asked for that was slightly unusual created many problems*restaurants in the hotel were of a very poor standard, breakfast was great for Japanese but very bad for western breakfast*japanese restaurant in hotel was very expensive and the food was ordinary*No gym, you have to pay 2,100 yen per person, per visit to use a gym that is a ten minute walk from the hotel *check-out took 30 minutes and then they couldnt work out the bill and we received an angry call from the driver who hadnt been paid for the airport transfer, this was unresolved as at the time we flew back to Australia. The disorganisation was unprofessional*We needed printed vouchers from our travel agent when checking in - this hotel lives in the dark ages

Overall, this was a fine place to spend a few days on business. The room was clean and the property is convenient for many venues (nothing is close to any hotels in Tokyo - the city is just too large). The hotel staff was very helpful with recommendations for restaurants and directions to attractions within walking distance. Breakfast on the 3rd floor is recommended - a great mix of Western and Eastern food.

Nice hotel, only stayed one night on business. Reception big, but a bit sole less and no where to sit to have meeting until coffer area opened! Staff friendly and helpful. Didn't eat breakfast due to early start. Room smallish. Surrounded by amusement area (roller coater etc) as next to Toyko Dome stadium.. but this was closed. Probably fun when open though. Would stay there again, no problem, but might try to find something a bit more characterful next time.

Stayed here for business for one night only. Rooms clean and fairly modern but really quite small. The room was comfortable but quite noisy. I would stay here again but I would happily give somewhere else a chance.

The rooms of Tokyo Dome Hotel are large for Tokyo standards but it still came out a bit cramped for our family of three with all our luggages. We had to move around some of the furniture in order to make our stuff fit. Apart from that, everything else was great. The rooms are clean, modern and well-equipped. There are ample amenities in the bathroom, and these are replenished daily. They provided us with bedroom slippers, and even brought a small sized one for our young daughter. LAN Internet is free, but a wireless router can be rented from the concierge at a rate of ¥300 for 5 days. The staff is also very efficient, helpful and polite. Tokyo Dome City is in itself an attraction with a shopping complex, an amusement park, a spa, the Tokyo Dome and lots of restaurants around. You could easily spend the entire day here without getting bored especially if you have kids. But while the complex is full of things to do, the area where it is located is more of a business district and not a lot of famous sights are within walking distance from the hotel. There is a JR and a Metro Station nearby where you can take a train to other attractions within Tokyo, but some rides can be quite long given its distance from everything else. Overall, this is a great place to stay in when you're in Tokyo especially if you don't mind taking the train a lot to get to other places you wish to visit.

If the price was not so high l would have given this hotel an excellant, so see if you can get a discounted package deal.The hotel its self is in an excellant part of Tokyo right next to a baseball stadum / semi theme park and shopping centre but still close to everything.The rooms are modern, clean, large and comfortable. The included breakfast was a good mix of Japanesse and western food.

If you can get past the price, this is a good choice for a stay in Tokyo. Easy access to JR station which allows easy touring of Tokyo. Make sure to catch a Giants game if they are in town, a different experience from an American baseball park. Lots of restaurants in the area, but pretty quiet if you are seeking nightlife. Be sure to watch the train schedule if you head out for the night elsewhere in the city, as the trains stop running sometime after midnight.

Good view over the city, but this part of the city is quiet at night, no so many neon lights, the rooms are spacious enough, so is the bathroom, too bad all the channels on the TV are Japanese shows, difficult for us tourist to be updated on the news and events. the plus side is that the name of the hotel itself speaks for its attraction, it has a dome where there are plenty of shops, entertainment, and a small amusement park, including a roller coaster. just recently the site of a convention on cosplay. thus hundreds of people in costumes. interesting site to see. the breakfast is also above average when it comes to serving western cuisine, since Japanese cuisine is always a standard in any Japanese Hotel. thus tourist who are not use to Japanese food, may still have a good breakfast. there is also a starbucks just beside the Hotel if you like that kind of coffee, then the subway and JR trains are just around the corner. overall it is worth the slightly expensive cost of it. so I do recommend this place for those who don't mind a little extra.

The Tokyo Dome Hotel is one of my all-time favorite hotels.- Rooms are large for Tokyo standards. Clean, well-equipped, very calm and quiet. And internet (by LAN) is now free.- View from most rooms are fantastic.- Location: It's at the Dome entertainment complex, which means that you can let the kids roam free (well, kind of) without fear that they have to cross major roads or get lost. As long as you are at the Dome area, you can not possibly loose sight of the hotel. The area features a Spa and fitness center, a medium size shopping mall and rides and entertainments, not to mention plenty of restaurants and the Dome stadion itself.- Plenty of cosplay action over the weekends.- Staff is kind and efficient.- Transport: The Dome is on top of the Suidobashi subway station and next to the JR line. You can get to Shinjuku or Ginza in about 20 mins.What's not to like? Very little. Hotel can for some people feel soulless and sterile, though I don't share that view myself. Breakfast is nice but expensive, so walk a few blocks away and get your breakfast at a Dennys or Mos Burger. Biggest problem is probably that the lifts tend to be crowded during peak time.But who cares? It's a comfortable, fun and exciting place. I'll go there any chance I get.One piece of advise: Book your room by hotel's own website. For a non-Japanese, it is frankly very hard to navigate and register on it, but you can get better deals than on the normal booking sites.

Spacious rooms (compared with others in Tokyo). Normal things you'd expect in a 4/5 star hotel room. Did appreciate wired internet access. Network cable supplied in room. Lifts can be a bit of a problem at peak times - especially breakfast and during morning rush hour. Self service restaurant great for mixing western and Japanese styles, but can be very busy at times. Convenient for Suidobashi station and a 711 within 150 metres. Exceedingly courteous staff. Infrequent bus service direct to Narita airport.

Here for World Baseball Classic and this lovely high-rise hotel is directly next to Tokyo Dome. Several restaurants in the hotel and shopping mall next door as well. Convenient to Japan Railroad and subway. Room comfortable, not luxurious, but very adequate. Several of the baseball teams staying here. Interesting to meet them in elevators and at breakfast. Recommended.

I have stayed at the Tokyo dome for two to four nights one or twice a year fopr the past 10 years. Initially this was a very comfortable hotel, with good service, located close to where I needed to do business. Over the years the quality seems to have slightly deteriorated, nothing major just little things. The 43rd floor bar was an outstanding place to have a drink, listen to some jazz and watch Tokyo at night. That changed a couple of years back when they removed the musci and the seating. Lastest is that they will charge extra if you want to check in early (1.10pm is too early?). Clearly the room is ready or they would not want to extract cash.On the plus side the staff are extremely helpful and speak very good English. the location is excellent with a number of good restaurants nearby. Going to a baseball game at the Dome is a great experience!

This is one of best hotel in Tokyo. I used sometimes for business and also private. If you dont plan to spend 200-300 dollars for international hotel but wanna stay nice place. This is one option.Location: you can find not only JR but also lots of metro lines then you can go any place very easily. Shuttle: Hotel offers direct bus to Narita/Haneda airports. It costs JPY 3000 to Narita airport.Services: Hotel staff are really friendly and nice. I love the atmosphere.Food: "Tankuma" is signature Japanese restaurant. I highly recommend to enjoy its breakfast. I also like bar located on 46th floor.Room: very clean. All necessary amenities (shampoo, night clothes) are equipped.Cost: depends. But if you stay more than 3 nights without any food, then you can find less than $100 per night.Hope it helps

Cambridge, Massachusetts, United States

review_body: Nice hotel, convenient to the Tokyo dome which was focus of the trip. Easy to access by subway (suidobashi station), also convenient for airport bus. Friendly helpful staff, most speak English. Would have been helpful to have more of the literature in English. Great city views, higher floors can see mt Fuji!

My husband and I stayed at the Tokyo Dome Hotel in early January for 7 nights. The hotel was one of the largest we ever stayed in. It had 42 floors. It is a well appointed hotel and the rooms were most comfortable and spacious. It is next door to the Dome itself with beautiful views of the Dome and the city., The cleanliness of the hotel was first rate. The rooms were always spotless. The internet connection for 300yen was truly a bargain and very convenient. The staff was fine, but not very helpful. For example I asked if there were smaller restaurants nearby and they could not give me any information. Yet we discovered hundreds of little restaurants just a few minutes from the hotel. This was my first trip to Japan and I found the prices quite expensive, including the hotel. Also when a couple shares a room, it seems that each person have to pay, rather than just paying for one room. The hotel restaurants were nice, but again quite expensive.Unfortunately breakfast was not included in the price of the room. The other positive thing about the hotel location is that it was close to the subway station so we were able to get to places with relative ease.

ラクーアに遊びに行くなら東京ドームホテルは隣にあるので便利かも今回は隣接の遊園地が目的だったのでお正月に最初に宿泊したホテルがここだった。朝食はホテル内にある洋食か和食を選べた。ラグジュアリーなホテルに泊まりなれている人は普通に感じるかもしれない。窓から見える東京ドームや観覧車の夜景は綺麗だと思う。水道橋駅からは徒歩圏内のホテルIs the Tokyo Dome hotel convenient in the next thing if I go out to 「LaQua」 to play?The hotel where I stayed at first for New Year holidays because an adjacent amusement park was a purpose this time was here.The breakfast was able to choose the Western food in the hotel or Japanese food.I may feel people getting used to staying at the luxurious hotel to be commonly.I think that Tokyo Dome and the night view of the Ferris wheel to see from a window are clean.It is a hotel within the range of the foot from Suidobashi Station

I normally stay at this hotel on business trips to Tokyo. The location is excellent, easy access to the Dome itself ....it's part of the building. Rooms are always clean and spotless. Staff are OK but lack some of the finer customer orientation you see in other hotels. Internet is free as long as you have a LAN connection, but if like me you travel with an iPad and need wifi in the room then you pay extra, which I find just unacceptable in these days. The device you get to hook up the wifi is relatively straight forward but it's not as simple as entering a wifi code. You effectively hook up a router in your room. The reception area is vast, but again has no soul, there is no centre and you often find large groups of tourists sitting in all sorts of places. This can make it difficult for impromptu meetings. It's a fine hotel but the niggles make it only average for me.

I stayed her for 3 days in December, 2012 for a business meeting. The hotel is large and comfortable. The rooms are decent sized for a Japanese hotel. Free wireless internet was fast and convenient. The breakfast buffet was a bit on the thin side for comparable hotels.

Spacious room for Japan standard. Convenience for food. Buffet breakfast is acceptable level.Short walking distance and you can find amusement park, cafe, food court, convenience store and some shopping.Feature Tour

I stayed 1 night for my concert trip in Tokyo. The best location for joining any events at Tokyo Dome. Nice room with nice amendities. Great Location. Near the stations with only a few minutes walk. Right inside the Tokyo Dome City attraction. Plenty of restaurants and convenience stores around the hotel. But some weak points as below:There were many people check in at the same time (properly most of them attending the same event), I wait for about one-hour for check in. As I am one of the people who would attend the event, so I understand the situation and feel acceptable for waiting such a long time. But I just wonder if someone who don't know there is an event... would feel angry for waiting a hour for check in. The time for waiting the lift is also long. The tower hotel with over 30 floors. But there are only a few lifts with really slow speed. But I like the glass lift with beautiful view.

This is a good location if traveling with family, though as with all things Tokyo, the space will be tight. The subway is across the street, tons of restaurants with both cheap and expensive eats nearby, an attached amusement park and right next to Tokyo Dome Stadium. The hotel offers a buffet for all meals which is of mediocre fair. Pricing is decent and the free wired internet service is solid. The service was absolutely fantastic.

Stayed here for 4 nights while on business. Room was on non-smoking floor - typical size for Tokyo, but well appointed. Beds are firm and not overly sized. Heating/ac quiet and efficient. Bathroom was clean and amenities average. TV has only one English language channel - CNN. Internet was free - wired...for fee - wireless. Food in hotel restaurants above average quality. Next to Tokyo Dome and shopping area. Would return to this hotel.

Stayed 8 nights and its a nice hotel decorated in sports theme given there's a giant baseball stadium behind it. Room is a little small in comparison to our normal rooms; but in Japan, it's huge.... Staff is always polite, attentive and go out of their way to make sure you're looked after. It's like every staff is an invisible butler who anticipate what you need before you realised! Though it's primary a business hotel, it does pay individual attention to each guest where guest with young children and baby prams are always helped regardless of weather or hour, it's like the hotel runs on House Elf if you're a harry potter fan! its only 2 minutes walk to the subway, 5 minutes to a JR line station, and a fleet of taxis at your doorstep even if it's 4 in the morning! And a 7 Eleven next to the hotel, a shopping mall and theme park behind the hotel and a really crazy roller coaster that is 20 storey high behind the hotel for the adrenaline(*suicidal) junkie in you!!Love it and will definitely return!!

the Dome Hotel is very conveniently located.rooms and bathrooms are fineInternet connection is free of charge although only via cablebreakfast buffet is expensive but very big and variate.the hotel has a very good (although expensive) Japanese traditional restaurant

Beware that they might overcharge you.Minibar: Please ask them to clear the drinks in your minibar!! They will charge you even if you never even open the fridge.Bill: Although their bills are messy, please always check it clearly before you leave the hotel.

i stayed at this hotel for 8 nights total. After along flight and then a 2 hour bus ride from the airport, I was very happy to sleep! The beds were comfortable and the rooms were decent. The best prt was the view. The first 4nights I was on the side facing the baseball stadium. The other nights I was on the opposite side. Simply amazing. My colleagues and I simply gathered in one room, turned off all the lights and opened the curtains to admire the awesome view of Tokyo. The prices for the mini bar / fridge in the room was very well priced as well. This surprised me. Breakfast was fantastic. There was a choice of a traditional Japanese style bfast and a more versatile bfast area. There was spaghetti on the buffet and it was the best spaghetti I have ever had. I was able to wake up fairly early and walk. I am an educator and of course, was interested in the schools. I walked and walked and ended up at a couple of Shinto shrines, a middle school, and could have walked to the imperial palace if I wanted too :) The metro is near by. Just a short walk. All and all, I was very pleased with my stay at the Tokyo Dome. There is also a McDonalds near by and a few Karaoke places. Good times :)

Stayed in the hotel already several times in the past five years for business trips and would recommend it to others. Due to special company rates we get very reasonable rates for the rooms on excellency floors in 39th - 41st floor, so I can't really judge on price/performance ratio for individual travellers. Nevertheless the excellency rooms are: Spacious enough, very clean, comfortable, quiet. Quick internet connection via LAN cable complimentary.Choice of international TV channels very limited - currently only Japanese + CNN (Asia) - they had also BBC World in the past but it's no longer available. For guest staying in the excellency rooms continental breakfast is complimentary in the lounge on 40th floor. (Simple continental breakfast, o.k. for 2-3 days in a row, but might get boring afterwards). Free tea/coffe + cakes in the afternoon & even alcoholic drinks till 9.p.m in the excellency lounge - but who has the time...). Hotel offers several restaurants, but unfortunately neither spa nor fitness room.Service is excellent, very friendly and helpful. Hotel has direct NRT or HND airport access by limousine bus. Alternatively for NRT take Skyliner to/from Ueno station + taxi. Also convienently located at JR Suidobashi station, Korakuen Metro and next to Tokyo Dome baseball stadium + Tokyo dome City. Several convenience stores within walking distance and plenty of additional restaurants of all price levels on the other side of the JR line or in Tokyo Dome City amusement park.

I spent a couple of nights here this past week. Unfortunately, this was a pretty forgettable experience.To begin, I was placed in a smoking room. When I reached the room, I immediately called the front desk - they apologized, but only set someone up to spray the room with scent. This didn't help at all, of course.The hotel overall is in need of an update. The hall carpets are dingy and the room feels dated. The bathroom is fine, but the quality of supplies is middling at best, particularly compared to other similarly priced hotels in TokyoThe location is fine. The hotel is right next to the Tokyo dome, and is easy accessed via the Suidobashi station.The breakfast is fairly good, but expensive.Overall, probably not worth the cost - I've had better luck staying at smaller Japanese-style hotels, which offer much more character for the cost, and better service.

Located right next to the Tokyo Dome, this is a great hotel to stay at with kids. There is a little amusement park right out the door. The elevator in the hotel is like an amusement ride for kids. It is glass and you can see the entire city as you go up. The rooms were fine-not the most luxurious but clean and comfortable. The only negative is that there is not a gym/pool on the property. For 2000 Yen, the hotel arranges for you to go to a gym and pool nearby.

10 day stay for business. Pleasant and efficient room and good internet connection.Nice choice of restaurants in the hotel and plenty of foodplaces nearby.Spectacular view in top floor restaurant/bar.Next to the Tokyo Dome stadium. As there were a series of concerts, this had an upside and downside: large crowds made walking in the area sometimes difficult and the concerts got into the rooms (even at 21st floor one could enjoy the music) but the crowds existed of typical Japanese teens - so a fantastic view on contemporary Japan - and the concerts finished before 8 pm. The connection to the airports with Airport Limousine busses is very efficient.

Exclellent business hotel. Its large hotel that runs very efficiently. Huge lobby area,where you can meet business asociates, plentiful restaurants and walking distance to metro/public transport. Rooms are large (by Japanese standards) with a well stocked (with toiletries /towels/gowns/slippers) bathroom. comfortable beds , individually controlled aircon and free internet. ideal for busienss person.only criticism is that the TV channels are limited - only English channel was CNN.

Everything is easy when entering this hotel. It is situated next to a permanent fairground attraction and the tokyo Dome. Check in and out go very efficient. Rooms are in a clean state, for internet you have to search a bit if you want to have it cabled.Beds are fine, 4 pillows, roomservice punctual, complementary newspaper each morning

review_body: I stayed here for my first and last night of my 9-day, 8-night stay in Japan. I'd say this was the (overall) best hotel out of the 4 I stayed in for several reasons.1. Staff. They were very courteous, effificient, accommodating and spoke English proficiently.2. Facilities.i. They have several spacious conference rooms, 2 of which I'm sure accommodates over 100.ii. They have a very spacious lobby - a great rendezvous point, esp. if you don't know Japanese and you want to meet friends; they'll recognize the place and easily get to you. It has a cafe too.iii. They have a pool but I never got to use it; however, it was located strategically in an upper floor of the hotel and is very inviting.iv. Hotel restaurant; I only tried their breakfast buffet and it was good! A cross-over between modern Japanese and Western food with a very generous seating capacity. Conducive for families, big groups and "meal meetings" (i.e. working lunches or over-time work dinners). 3. Ammenities.i. Toiletries, towels (3 sizes), slippers and a hair dryer are always provided for. They are environmental friendly as you can indicate if you choose not to have your towel changed for 2 days or more.ii. They also have a water heater and 2 variants of tea, as well an ice cube container.iii. Envelopes, postcards, a writing pad and a laundry bag are in the desk drawer.iv. Sliding closet with hangars, a flashlight and shoe fitter. Lights turn on upon activity.4. Location. It's surround by almost everything! Beside it is a stadium, a shopping complex (restaurants, shops, arcade, etc.) It's near a train station, a mall and more shops, many of which are open in the "mornight" hours.5. Technological services.i. LAN internetii. TVii. Room key cardThe aforementioned reasons made my stay at the Tokyo Dome Hotel a comfortable one. The room was very conducive for R&R after a busy day and served as an "Fortress of Solitude" despite it being central to a variety places. One of the down-sides is that there is no Wi-Fiand most shops around it close early. Another down-side s that the hotel or surrounding area is not Wi-Fi friendly to foreigners.
One of the best hotels in Tokyo. I especially loved the view.

Stayed for 2 nights and am quite satisfied with the rather strategic location. The buffet breakfast spread was satisfactory. The shops in LaQua, the shopping complex within a walking distance closes at 9pm but there is a supermarket on the ground floor that stays opened pass 9pm though.Apparently, there isn't much double beds available and we have to settle for 2 beds. I find the lifts to be quite fast. The room air-con doesn't seem to be as cold as the hotels in other countries. I think this could be the way the air-con is programmed as I find similar temperature in another hotel I stayed in Tokyo.

The odd thing about the Tokyo Dome Hotel is that it is a good business hotel set next to a baseball stadium and an amusement park. The great benefit from this location is that it is a transportation focal point for the metro lines and trains. You can get around the city effectively from here. Sometimes you have to negotiate around people attending ball games and all, but these operations are coordinated smoothly, so no great problem there. The hotel rooms are comfortable. Firm beds, good water pressure, counter space in the bathrooms, expansive views, enough hangers. The breakfast buffet is good and diverse but the same every day. The staff are very friendly and proficient in English. It is a good mix of Western and Asian hospitality.

Single rooms are similar size to double rooms. Very suitable for business person, Fantastic view over Tokyo. Korakuen garden is next to the hotel and the entrance fee is only 300yen.You can have a nice walk in the historical Japanese garden.

I absolutely loved Tokyo Dome Hotel. I thought it was such an exciting hotel to stay in, in such a cool and trendy area of town (Tokyo Dome).The hotel is a massive sky-scraper and we were on the 34th floor (I requested a high room which the staff kindly obliged). It was amazing going up and down in the elevator each day just taking stock of the incredible view (from the glass elevator on the side of the tower…not for those with vertigo!).The room was a good size and the bed was big and comfortable. I had nice tea and coffee making facilities and free connection to the internet. The best thing though was the views!There are many restaurants and places to eat in this hotel, it can be slightly confusing and a little overwhelming but you can not complain that you have no choice!I had the buffet breakfast one morning, and room service the next. The room service menu I felt was very expensive, and the buffet breakfast was also quite expensive but the choice was immense and the food was delicious.The staff were exceptionally friendly and warm towards us even though it was a very busy hotel.We did have a little complication paying the bill but this was rectified by the hotel staff quickly and efficiently.The hotel is very exciting, many people clearly use the lobby as a meeting place for the Tokyo Dome area, but I liked that as it gave an electrifying atmosphere to the hotel!I really loved this hotel, and was sad to leave it.

Me and friends went to tokyo for one weekend trip and we stayed at at tokyo dome hotel, located next to dome city and across the road there are izakaya ( japanese local pub)It was beyond our expectation, the hotel rooms are huge and the staff are very friendly, thebreakfast is also great.Will consider togo back there again for my next tokyo visit

I've stayed here numerous times on business. Pros: nice if slightly bland rooms, excellent staff, very good breakfast and stunning views of Tokyo's skyline from the skybar - Mount Fuji is visible on a clear day. Cons: no on site gym facilities (you can use the nearby sports complex as a guest) wifi is difficult to access, if at all. And a the lifts are slow. If you are meeting ever punctual Japanese colleagues allow extra time for the lifts. Good location, convenient for the metro, and obviously the Tokyo Dome next door.

review_body: Excellent location if you have a seminar at the Tokyo Dome as it is just a walking distance. There's a mini theme park with roller coaster ride outside the hotel which is quite exhilarating. Has a good range of choices for breakfast and loving the yukata provided in the rooms ;-)
A beautiful hotel in an active area with a great view of Tokyo from our room.

I have been staying there repeatedly for business reasons, usually for a few days, last time in Jan 2012. The rooms are well furbished and comfortable. Check-in and check-out are efficient. While I saw a lot of foreigners in this hotel I noticed that the hotel is not really accomodating them. The breakfast buffet, while large, does not include cheese. The hotel does not have a broad variety of international TV channels, all Japanese. My colleague and I both got up early to go for the gym only to discover that there is none. The bar on top of the building is really nice but closes rather early. Nevertheless the overall impression is good, the atmosphere welcoming. The hotel is close to a number of restaurants and suits our purpose. A well equipped and modern gym would be a nice upgrade for the average business traveller who is fighting against weight gain all the time.

This is one of the top hotel in Tokyo. Very good organized and fast with check in and out. It provides everything you can think of, besides WiFi in the room. This is rather disappointing but the cable internet is free.The breakfast is outstanding and very rich in choice.Great location in Tokyo right next to the Tokyo Dome with also acts as an convention center.

I stayed here on business for a couple nights on a two week trip in Japan. The other hotels I stayed at were very typical tiny hotels with nothing in the way of creature comforts, which made me appreciate the Tokyo Dome Hotel that much more. The hotel is situated right next to the Tokyo Dome, hence the name. You are surrounded by a multi level amusement park that was very fun to walk around in the evening. The restaurants on site are very good. We had Tempanyaki in the hotel and it was very good quality, although a bit overpriced in my opinion. They also had some delicious local craft beers had me in awe. The breakfast was one of my favorite parts of Tokyo Dome Hotel. I had been eating rice and miso soup for a week and a half for breakfast and it was nice to walk into a GIGANTIC breakfast buffet that included Japanese and American style breakfast in very good quality. Loads and loads of fresh fruit, eggs (made to order), bacon, sausage, rice, ham, japanese pickles, and tons more. The front desk spoke good English and were very helpful. I will definitely stay here next time I am in Tokyo.

I was in Tokyo for business in December and agree with the other recent reviews. I accidentally left behind some expensive ties and other clothes and didn't realize this until I was back in the U.S. I called the front desk and was sent to the housekeeping office. They'd found my items and after a quick exchange of e-mails, they sent them to my home free of charge. The items arrive nicely folded in their own individual packages. Very Japanese, very quick, and very much appreciated! (P.S. The wired internet connected was fast as well.)

review_body: I was in Tokyo on business and although this is not a top of the range hotel, the rooms were spacious and clean. There are lots of places nearby to eat and an easy subway ride to harajuku shinjuku. The roller coaster etc were not in operation at the dome, but there was a great little supermarket under that laqua shopping area that had European bottled water etc for anyone who might be concerned about water quality. I came back to Tokyo a few days later and stayed in a more expensive hotel more centrally located, but I preferred the dome.

This hotel is located next to ball park of Tokyo Giants.So, off season rate is really good. and best is very close to Akihabara !!If you wanna spend most of time there. It's one of the best choice. Also, Kagurasaka, ancient geisha district, is close. you'll find bunch of great restaurants here !!

Stayed at this hotel twice in 2011 and on both occasions, more than happy with the level of service and the rooms were excellent for the price. I used the basic online package of room only and had my breakfast at the lobby cafe. The hotel has excellent train service within a 100mtr walk and is easy to get to and from Narita airport by executive coach at a cost of 3000Yen.

This a a really good value hotel. Nothing personal with this hotel. A bit small rooms but the rate is good and location is really good. There are 3 subway stops within walking distance. Breakfast is good and also the Korean resturant in the hotel is great! This was my 3 stay here and I do not think I will choose another hotel when I am in Tokyo.

A very great hotel with alternatives route to the airport: Limousine Bus or Subway. Taxi also stand by.Very nice view and surroundings, especially near the great GIANTS home base. Also easy to have access for having some Japanese meals: from fast food to heavy meal.Great breakfast provided and very nice services!Awesome!
Nice and clean, well positioned especially if you are a baseball fan (Tokyo Dome is on the side), maybe not too elegant or fancy but good value for money and kept clean and sharp all the time.

I have been a guest at TDH 3 times - the most recent was this March 2011. The hotel is large, modern, and clean. The staff there are very friendly and quick to help with luggage or opening the door. The hotel is serviced with 6 elevators of which 3 go to the upper floors. Depending on the time of day you may encounter a 10 minute wait for an open elevator. Rooms are good size (huge by Japan standards) and the beds are hard. Views on floors 20+ are amazing. The included breakfast (on the 2nd or 3rd floor) is excellent.Location of the hotel is excellent. Getting to the hotel from local airports (Haneda and Narita) is simple with the limo bus. I believe the cost was 3K YEN for a one way and they deliver directly to the hotel. I wish I had time to take in a Giants baseball game but it never worked out. Lots of dining options both in the hotel, around the hotel, or just a 10 minute walk to local street. I found the food options better on the street and the prices were cheaper as well. That said the hotel and dome area is still an excellent dining alternative. Beware the drink/food prices in the hotel bar - very very expensive. Outside the hotel front entrance is a Starbucks coffee and around the corner is a 7-11 to shop for snacks/water/beer/sake/alcohol. The Dome has an amusement park and lots of shopping and dining as well.Two different train lines are just 5 minutes walk away giving you full access of the city and beyond.As a side note the March 2011 earthquake hit the day I checked out. I was stranded at the TCAT bus terminal but had colleagues at the hotel who were leaving the following day. They said the hotel swayed heavily (as designed) but remained safe and that the hotel staff remained helpful and friendly despite the situation.If I travel to Tokyo again I will definitely look to stay at the TKH.

The location of this hotel was very convenient as it was close to subway and close to a shopping mall and there are many restuarants nearby.Rooms soundproof and spacious and if you get a higher floor you'll have a spectacular view.The internet was kind of a problem though not working properly in all rooms, for instance it worked better in my colleague's room than mine. Some websites were displayed in Japanese.
Tokyo hotel in good location. Rooms are good size and well equipped. Views from the upper floors are spectacular. One downside: Cable internet only and it was problematic to make it work.

This is my favourite hotel in Tokyo whereI have stayed many times when I visit for business purposes and the service is always perfect. For leisure travellers it is a bit expensive but the location is great close to Suidobashi, Marunochi and Kurakoen metro stations, the Tokyo Dome amusement park just outside the door (don't miss the rollercoaster) and there is a fantastic Japanese garden close to Iidabashi 5 minutes walk from the hotel. The surrounding area is full of restaurants if you don't want to visit the ones in the hotel (which is ok) and the two bar's is nice but I prefer the skybar which has a fantastic view over Tokyo.

The hotel is stunning, both inside and out, and in a great location. We stayed in a room on the 37th floor, and even after ten days I was still blown away by the view every time I looked out the window.It was not the largest room ever but there was enough space to be comfortable. The bathroom was very modern and always spotless. The bed was extremely comfortable, and definitely helped me to recover from the jet lag!There is a great range of restaurants within the hotel, and more a short walk away. The Artist's Cafe on the 43rd floor was my favourite - the staff were incredibly friendly, the food was great and the cocktails were even better. We also frequently visited Rilassa - I found this slightly misleading as it is described as an Italian restaurant, and there is very little Italian food available, but they do a very good breakfast and a generous buffet serving a variety of Asian food.We were lucky to find this hotel while it was on sale, as it was outside what we could normally afford. However, if the opportunity arose, I would love to stay there again.

I've stayed in Tokyo Dome 6 times in the last 4 years. Everytime I go back, feels just right at home I must say. Unfortunately for all 6 times they were for work and not for leisure. Staff efficiency is very good, from the moment we check-in, till we check-out and even the concierge service. Rooms are clean and well furnished, I like the free internet in the room which keeps me connected to my love ones after a full day meeting. Rooms are spacier than Hong Kong hotels too. The location itself is not bad. There's the LaQua complex just across which is where you would take the Tokyo Metro. You can find food here very easily. There's also the LaQua plaza which offers more choices (if you speak Japanese that is...) and the pricing would be better than eating in the hotel of course. The hotel is not far from Tokyo station which is near the CBD and very near to Ikebukuro which is a large shopping district. If you'd like to go to Disneyland, you'll have to go from Tokyo station anyway. But going to Asakusa is far..... Nevertheless, the theme park below the hotel transforms to a myriad of colours at night. An absolutely joyful place for photographers. Overall, if I were to go to Tokyo on my own account, I will definitely stay here again. Just love it!

I stayed here for three nights, paid for by my company. I had a room on the 33rd floor. The room was large; a very good size with a big, comfortable bed, and had a breathtaking view over Tokyo.Service was OK -- as you would expect for this standard of hotel. Professional with good English.The location is very convenient with easy access to the Suidobashi JR and subway stations. However it is part of the Tokyo Dome concert hall / amusement park complex, with is not really my idea of a "nice" or restful location.Ultimately I was a little underwhelmed with my overall experience.- the hotel is enormous; more like a city within a city, including overpriced souvenir shops and wedding photo galleries. Not really my scene, but that is personal preference.- the lifts are impressive glass affairs with wonderful, vertigo-inducing views. But they are s.l.o.w., and when they do finally arrive, the doors slam shut on you before you can struggle in with your suitcases.- only wired internet access: no in-room wi-fi.- Mineral water is charged (and 2x the going rate). I'm accustomed to hotels providing at least a couple of free bottles. No excuse for a hotel at this price point.- No iron or trouser press in room; I had to call housekeeping for them. (there was no problem communicating though, and they came quickly. But it's not exactly convenient).Overall, the experience was O.K., but a hotel of this size is always going to be a bit of an impersonal affair. And it was. Prior to checking in at the Dome, I stayed in the Hotel Niwa, nearby. Niwa was significantly cheaper and had smaller rooms, but I much preferred staying there. Cleaner, more modern, and better service and facilities I needed. Moving into the Dome was a bit of a disappointment after that.

This hotel is in a great location, near metro stations and is part of an amazing shopping, eating, and sports complex. I visited this hotel with a large group of colleagues so service was excellent. The elevators are slow and there can be long lines for the elevator so be prepared to lose all personal space when you squeeze into an elevator but your in Tokyo and that is just how it is there. Buffet breakfast was good, really good and the room was always clean. I'm not a big fan of the beds. They were twin size but when in Japan do as the Japanese I suppose. Main hang up was that the beds were hard. Is that a Japanese thing too? Might have been more comfortable to sleep on the floor. Overall great hotel and looking forward to my next visit.

Professional and courteous staff. Location and convenience to public transportation and shopping/sightseeing. Nice views. Clean rooms. Sometimes slow elevators. The Tokyo Dome Hotel is nice. The staff is friendly, courteous, and very helpful. The hotel facilities and guest rooms are kept very clean, as is the entire Tokyo Dome City.The hotel is just a few minutes walking distance from 4 train/subway stations. Suidobashi (JR Sobu line), Suidobashi (Mita line), Kasuga (Mita & Oedo lines), and Korakoen (Marunouchi & Namboku lines).Restaurant : Buffet Breakfast is good.

This was my first trip to Japan. Really loved the views from the hotel! The hotel rooms are well furnished. The location is great - near to baseball stadium and close to aki habra.Its located near to the metro stations. The hotel is located near to the shopping area as well!! Really loved my stay!!

We stayed at Tokyo Dome because it's within 15 minutes walk of Japan Karate Association headquarters, but it's even closer to the Kodokan. What a nice change from the "business hotel" I stayed at on my last visit! Although the rooms are small by North American standards, the clean, modern design prevents them from feeling cramped. Everything at this hotel is excellent. A couple of small points to note: although there's no wireless internet (wireless is virtually impossible to find in Japan), there is free wired internet access, and a patch cord is in a drawer in each room; and the restaurant/bar on the top floor is mostly restaurant, so if you go up for just a drink, you'll be stuck in a relatively small portion of the floor.

Our stay in the Tokyo Dome Hotel was great, we stayed in the 34th Floor (been upgraded, can't tell you why). The view was outstanding, we could see the Tokyo Dome and the surrounding amusement park. I think the room was about 18000 yen, which is a phenomenal price for such a view in Tokyo.The room itself was pretty small, with the standard bathroom (also small) It's okay, but nothing special. Staff was helpful, check in- and out were really fast, newspaper has been delivered every morning to the door. The location though is a little bit tricky for first timers in Tokyo; you will have to change a least once to get to tourist hot spots (expect Akihabara I think...). But not a big deal. Watch a Giants game if possible at the Dome, great experience.Overall a good hotel with great views (if you are lucky) and nice staff. Will stay there again.

Used Domu hotel several times. Normal high tokyo service and quality standards, upgrade rooms are good size, easy to get to Kasumigaseki and central areas, also tourist areas. Both Japanese and various foreign guests, english no problem. Top floor Artist bar and restaurant guaranteed to impress your guests but reserve window table. Fun to watch antics in the Dome amusement park next door. 200 m from Edo period Koishikawa Korakuen stroll garden.

Extremely well provided rooms, great view overlooking the city. Price point was very attractive. Direct travel connections with Narita airport, centrally located hotel for business meetings and sight seeing. Great ambience.

I travelled to Tokyo on business and was put up at the Tokyo Dome Hotel by the client. The hotel is centrally located and is easy to locate as it is attached to the world famous 'Tokyo Dome' stadium. The staff spoke good english and were very polite and helpful. The room was spotless and very contemporary though a little small compared with hotels in other Asian cities. Having said that it was larger than other hotels in Kyoto (which were mere matchboxes). The staff don't accept tips (considered offensive) and will not touch your valuables (even my small change was neatly arranged in a row after the room was serviced). The toilets are brilliant! The breakfast buffet was very good as was the room service. The rooftop bar (27th floor?) had a brillant view of the city skyline. The stadium is 2 minutes away from the hotel and there is a small amusement park barely a 3 minute walk away. The train station is a 5 minute walk and taxis are not a problem.

The Tokyo Dome Hotel is one of Tokyo's best economic hotels, but unfortunately it's a bit expensive, that's why I gave it 3 points for value. By all means don't pay full price, always go through a travel site and book at a discounted rate.By Tokyo standards, the rooms are spacious! We had a triple room, which was just a twin room with an extra bed wedged in. I later went back and stayed in the normal twin room and it was really roomy. The colors and lighting are really soft and relaxing, and it's so quiet. The view from the upper floors is fantastic, so try to request something high up. In the winter you can see Mt. Fuji, so request that side of the hotel if you are going in winter or early spring. The bathrooms are spacious and have the high tech washlets, if you're into full service toilets. There is a minibar in the room, but it's expensive, like everywhere else in the world, so it's cheaper just to buy stuff at the convenience store and store it in the fridge. We went to Akihabara (4 minutes away on the subway) and bought some dvd's (I live in Japan, so region coding doesn't matter). When we got back to the hotel, we called and asked for a dvd player, less than 5 minutes later, there was a polite employee in our room attaching it for us. He gave a quick overview of the buttons on the remote (written in Japanese) and bowed and left. There was no charge for the dvd player rental. I wonder if they have gaming systems...The location of the hotel is great! It's 12 minutes to Shinjuku, about 4 minutes to Akihabara (10 minutes if you walk it) and Tokyo stations. It's across the street from Suidobashi station, which is not as crowded as other parts of Tokyo, even though there is an amusement park and baseball stadium there.

The Tokyo Dome Hotel is nice. The view from our 29th floor room was spectacular. It faced south, right toward Tokyo Tower. The staff is friendly, courteous, and very helpful. All staff I interacted with spoke enough English to understand our needs. We were always acknowledged by staff wherever we were in the hotel. The hotel facilities and guest rooms are kept very clean, as is the entire Tokyo Dome City/LaQua area. We never felt insecure or under-served while there. The hotel is just a few minutes walking distance from 4 train/subway stations. Suidobashi (JR Sobu line), Suidobashi (Mita line), Kasuga (Mita & Oedo lines), and Korakoen (Marunouchi & Namboku lines). Using the trains and subway is easy, especially if you get a “suica” card. The card is good on all Tokyo trains and subway lines. It was our first trip to Tokyo and we had no problems getting around the city by rail only. We never had to ride a bus or taxi. My only (very minor) complaints: 1) The carpet in our room, although very clean, was showing wear and tear, along with a lot of little stains, and the hallway carpet on our floor was bunched up in spots from the room cleaning carts. 2) The elevator service is slow at times. Avoid the elevators during peak check-in times and after events at the Tokyo Dome let out (there are signs that warn of up to 30 minute waits after Dome events). A couple of times, we waited probably 5-7 minutes for an elevator even though it appeared to be a slow time at the hotel. So as you can see, my complaints are very minor issues.A couple tips:If you don’t smoke, be sure to reserve a non-smoking room. I believe under 10% of the rooms in the hotel are non-smoking. Luckily, we got a non-smoking room.Be sure to take a laptop with you and use the in-room data access. I didn’t, and had to use the “100 Yen for 6 minutes” computer in the lobby area. There are only 2 of them in the business center and there were a couple times when there were people waiting for me to get done.I would love to stay at the Tokyo Dome Hotel the next time we travel to Tokyo!

I have stayed in many hotels around the world. I love this hotel. The location is excellent, the rooms are very clean and there are so many shops, restuarants very nearby. I have stayed there twice. Would definitely recommend staying there.

It is in a wonderful location, an excellent hotel with multiple restaurants.! It is also located in the Tokyo Dome City where there are amusements, restaurants, and a shopping mall...not to mention, the home stadium of the Tokyo Giants baseball game.It is located within a block of the Metro and two blocks from the JR train station. All aspects of service were outstanding; nothing missed! Many employees know English. Were so kind to supply a scale to help weigh my luggage.

review_body: I recently traveled to Tokyo on a business trip. Due to the close promiximity to my company, we stayed at the Tokyo Dome Hotel. It is a very clean hotel with friendly staff.It does get very crowded on the main floor lobby, but you don't notice that when on the floor of your hotel. Furthermore, the noise that emanates from the actual Tokyo Dome (concerts) is quite prevalent if you're staying on that side of the hotel.My room was adequately sized, and so was the bathroom. I was on the 26th floor and had a great view from my room. The restaurant also has very nice restaurants in the hotel. I highly recommend the Korean BBQ restaurant.Close to train station. I would stay there again despite the crowdedness.

The entrance to the Tokyo dome hotel was a little hard to find, coming from the subway station. But that's hardly a surprise, as it's a huge building, so it takes 10 minutes to even walk around it.The hotel has a staggering 48 floors, and an enormous reception desk. The staff is friendly and all spoke english. The rooms were spacious, clean and comfortable. My room was on the 24th floor and had an amazing view of the amusement park next to the hotel. The hotel has an english speaking tourist office and a shuttle to the airport, both of which were very useful in my case.

This hotel was beautiful - the service exceptional - the cleanliness unsurpassed - and the artist's cafe at the top of the hotel offered beautiful views of the city at night. It was close to public transit and next door to the oldest park in the city. We even were able to witness a wedding taking place at our hotel in an open-air meeting room during our stay.For years, I have been traveling with a poster of Jack and Robert Kennedy - a family tradition where the Kennedys appear in the background unobtrusively in holiday photos. During my stay in Tokyo, I lost one earring from a favorite pair. I wrote to the hotel staff from home (Madison WI) and asked if they had by chance found the earring. I promptly received a package with a very polite note saying they had not found the earring but they had found the enclosed poster - my Kennedys had been left behind in a drawer!! I was very impressed with the thoroughness of the staff and their kindness in returning my (priceless) poster.Susan

Have stayed here many times, the most recent being in October.The hotel is close to many subway/metro stations so the centre of Tokyo or Akihabara can be reached in less than 15 minutes.Rooms are spacious and comfortable, with fantastic views overlooking the Tokyo Dome. Ask for a higher floor room if possible!There are many restaurants suiting all tastes within the hotel with many more in the Tokyo Dome complex and close-by.The hotel staff are very helpful and will recommend places to go and eat.

I stay at the Tokyo Dome when I travel to Japan on business and it is a really comfortable and pleasant place. It's not really close to the trendier areas in Tokyo, but it is next to the train station and there are quite a few restaurants in the neighborhood to choose from (both asian and western).

Tokyo Dome Hotel is beautiful. Very nice inside and out. My room was on the 17th floor, and it overlooked the amusement park behind the hotel. The staff was extremely friendly, the room was large, and the hotel bar was very nice- with outstanding views.I seem to be in the minority on this, but I felt the location was a little out of the way. When going to Shibuya, Shinjuku, Harajuku, etc. there were normally at least one (if not 2 or 3) transfer involved. Not a huge deal, but there were certainly times that we got turned around coming back to the hotel. We had to make more of a concious effort to really memorize the routes we took (mostly subway) to make sure we could get back. Maybe we missed something, but this aspect seemed to be more challenging than staying in areas like Shinjuku- which was beyond easy to navigate.That said, Tokyo Dome is a gorgeous hotel, the roller coaster (Thunder Dolphin) and whole Tokyo Dome part behind the hotel was an added bonus and lots of fun!

The Tokyo Dome is a hi-rise hotel right next door to the baseball stadium of the same name. Ever felt like staying in a Tokyo Hotel like the one in Sophia Coppola's movie "Lost in Translation"? This is it. At night, you'll get great views of the immense city from pretty much every room in the building, except for the lower ones. During the day, the views are not so great because Tokyo is more beautiful at night. There are plenty of convenient shopping options in the complex nearby, including many restaurants (also within the hotel). Service, as everywhere in Japan, is impeccable. Hotel staff are corteous, polite, willing to help at all times. Parisians and New Yorkers could learn a lesson or two or a hundred from the japanese.Rooms are very, very clean and even spacious, in case you think every hotel room in Japan has tiny rooms. Bathrooms in Japan are something else, and you'd have to visit to learn details. On top of it all, this hotel is very affordable, much more so than any hotel of this category in any major city, be it New York, London or Rome. In fact, it is half the price of a hotel of the same quality in either one of the cities mentioned. Mine was a business trip, but I'd recommend this for a vacation as well. But do learn some japanese, because english is almost useless in Japan.

Tokyo Dome is situated at the center of Tokyo's metropolitan area, next to the Giants' baseball stadium and 5min walk to JR Suidobashi station.I have been in Japan many times for many years and this hotel is one of the bests for the money.It has a good restaurant for breakfast, a little pricy though, but all is pricy in Japan anyway. Highly recommended for business travelers.

We stayed at tokyo Dome Hotel twice in July 2006 and had a superb view from our room both times. The hotel is very clean and rooms pleasant, service friendly. The location of the hotel is great in many ways but especially if you fancy getting to know Japanese modern culture: a baseball game at the Dome, right next to the hotel. We had great time watching Tokyo Giants play! There is also many restaurants around the Dome and the hotel.

My husband and I booked the Dome for 4 nights.The hotel is part of a complex, so you will have easy acces to metro stations, restaurants and shops.The staff is really friendly and helpfull, not everybody speaks English but they will find for someone that will help you.If you book this hotel you will have a good time, the rooms are spacious and clean.I didn't have food in the hotel because quiet frankly , the restaurants were very expensive compare with the restarurants in the surranding areas.

I just stayed at the Tokyo Dome Hotel for two weeks on business/vacation and had a truly outstanding time. The hotel is certainly modern, brand new and gorgeous. The staff is so attentive and helpful with every possible amenity you could hope for. There are 9 restaurants and bars in this hotel- including, Chinese, French, Italian, Korean, Japanese, Continental and a Sizzler. The guest services desk will help you with anything right down to Japanese gift wrapping and shipping packages. In room massages are available for about $50 USD for 50 min. Just press a button on the phone. The hotel store has all of your basics as well as souvenirs and a nail salon. The lobby is a busy meeting place, full of excitement with a mezzanine wedding chapel; so if you are there on the weekend, enjoy the kitsch of a modern Japanese wedding! Or plan your own with their beautiful wedidng planning facilities.The technology of the hotel is very cool. You'll have to see for yourself! Japanese innovation is right on! High-speed internet is available if you ask for it in your room for an additional charge. Fortunately, there are no international compatibility issues!The hotel is part of a complex called Tokyo Dome City which is great for families. There is an amusement park right outside your window, but no disruptive noise. There is an open mall that leads to an indoor mall with numerous additional restaurants and western mall type stores. You will also find many American fast food chains right nearby, MacDonalds, Subway, KFC, Denny's, etc. There is also a beautiful spa in the mall that you get a discount on from the hotel. And of course the Tokyo Dome is there for baseball or whatever off-season event you may find.There are two trains nearby for convenient mass transit. Airport shuttle is available for about $30.00 USD to Narita, which is reasonable considering it is almost a 2 hour ride.The only drawbacks are minimal. The room service menu is limited. There is only an outdoor pool and no fitness facilities in the hotel.
